Along with McMurphy, Ms. Ratched, Martini, Billy Bibbit, and Chief were the characters that stuck out the most to me with their acting because of how well they showed their characters to be. The other characters of the movies seemed to be just background people to me. Overall, the movie was mediocre compared to book because of the details that were left out that I was looking forward to see.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: When I saw this great movie, at the age of 24, it moved me so much it was disturbing. I wanted Nurse Ratched to die so badly that I could hardly stand it. I'd never been so enraged by a character in a movie, before or since. I found everything about the movie to be excellent, especially the acting which included so many future big names in its cast.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I totally shocked, when I watch a part of the legend I ever saw in my life. I respect Jackie, because of his transformation, he's really talented guy, who makes me cry by laughing and by sadness.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Pictures, actors, lights, story...Everything in this movie is perfect
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Such real performances from the whole cast, so good that you forget they're actually acting!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: This film must be seen as an allegory
Review_body: This film is much more then meets the eye.It's an allegory about freedom, individualism, and will being intimidated by the system. The asylum is the world, and the hospital staff represents the authority.Which (despite first belief) is not negative.It's just a form of control, being seen from the rebel's view becomes negative.BUT,keeping a cold shoulder,there is no evil or despotic act being taken by nurse Ratchet.She acted just as any authority would in order to keep control,trying to please majority(for example the "vote for world series" scene).An important plot-point of the movie is when McMurphy finds out that most of the loonies are free to walk anytime, but,although unsatisfied,they prefer to remain within the asylum.Just as people in real life, prefer cold-rusty-confort, fearing a change.There are two rebels, but total-opposite types, hwo deny the system in their own way.One is McMurphy, the revolt-rising-rebel,a man of action,a lover of life (with all it's flaws & vices),that's motto is "at least I tried". And the other is "Chief" Brandon,the quiet-rebel, that locked himself away from the world.That's why the two become friends. McMurphy tries to set a change, and soon becomes a sort of spiritual leader and model for the rest of the group, threatening Ratchet's control.He is off-course put at ease, because in the end, "the system" will always reprime the individual. An excellent allegory it is! 10 out of 10!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: A truly stunning representation of mental health in an era where there was no awareness.
Review_body: The movie truly brought alive characters and lived up to the dynamic personalities that accompanied them in the novel. Jack Nicholson's performance was stellar and truly left you idolizing his masculinity and free spirit antics. Miss Ratchet, to this day, holds the title for most hated and vile villain!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
This is a typical "murder on the Orient express" black tragedy, "dramatic" is the best point of the film. Of course, the outcome is also very sad, unexpected, sharp turn down, caught off guard, tragic. A small madhouse harbors the ugliness and wickedness of humanity.
The stunning reversal of the ending is the perfect joke on the mental abuser.
One flew over the cuckoo's nest" will always make sense as long as there are people in the world who want to grab control of others.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
Review_body: In the movie One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest, Jack Nicholson, played the role of Randle McMurphy. McMurphy, who was a criminal that was sentenced for a short term in prison, decided to declare himself insane so that he can be placed into a mental institution. The reason that he does this is to have an opportunity to live in comfort and luxury rather than the harsh life in prison. To his surprise, McMurphy experience there was completely different from what he had expected.When McMurphy first met nurse Ratched, they both knew they were going to be each others enemies. I see Nurse Ratched as more of an authority figure who wants correct human behavior while McMurphy on the other hand, likes to do things as he please. I think that because he wants to make her more aggravated, he tries to teach the patients new things that she would not approve. He questions why the patients on why they would want to waste their life in such an institution when there is such a big world out there where there are some people who are even crazier. The story ends with a tragic ending. The nurse's authoritative behavior ultimately led to the death of a patient which also connected to the death of McMurphy in the end. After the chief kills McMurphy out of mercy, he then breaks the window and left the ward. A free man just like how McMurphy has always wanted them to be. I liked the ending because McMurphy was able to change at least one patient's view on life.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: "Cuckoo's Nest" is one of the most famous films. Jack Nicholson plays a convicted criminal, who make believe to be mentally ill to avoid going to jail. When he is committed to the sanatorium, he starts inciting the other prisoners to rebel against the strict administration. Jack Nicholson unforgettable performances the film features. The film is long, but absorbing and entertaining, and you will really care for all the characters right up to end.The principal artist Jack Nicholson gives his best in this movie, in particular during the scene where he plays cards with other patients, or when he pretends to be watching a baseball match. There is a comic part where Danny DeVito is plainly dancing in the basketball court. A social analysis of the movie is great fun. The ending of the film is truly a classic and dramatic.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest by Ben Parnell
Review_body:
The movie One Flew the Cuckoo's Nest is based on the novel written by Ken Kesey in 1962. This film is set in an Oregon psychiatric hospital with star, Jack Nicholson as Randle McMurphy, a new patient at the mental institution. McMurphy, a convict who has himself transferred to a state mental institution, throughout the movie he illustrates a stunningly persuasive portrait of a preeminently sane man being pushed to the outer limits of his sanity.This film takes place in 1959, when mental institutions were not only unfair and cruel to their patients but the outside world around these hospitals were completely unaware of what was happening within these facilities. It was believed that mental illness was caused by possession of demons and witchcraft based off of their abnormal behaviors that they did not understand. Novelist Ken Kesey made this novel one of the best sellers of the 1960's from his time working the "graveyard shift" as an orderly at a mental facility. He not only spoke to patients within the institution, he also voluntarily took psychoactive drugs like LSD as a part of the CIA mind control program to "become an advocate to use these drugs as a path to individual freedom". Academy award winner for best director of the film, Milos Forman, uses main character McMurphy to represent freedom and self-determination which oppresses the ward controlled by Nurse Ratched by protesting the rules of the institution with manipulation of the system to his advantage. He begins by getting transferred for evaluation from a prison farm to a mental institution assuming that it will be a less restrictive environment but is shortly mistaken when he faces the iron fist of Nurse Ratched who runs the psychiatric ward keeping her patients cowed through mental abuse, medication, and electric shock therapy maintaining a permanently grip on the mentally ill creating a harsh reality for the viewers of the film being how it was back then.
Later, the film pieces itself together and reveals McMurphy, Chief, and Cheswick are the only non-chronic patients sentenced to stay in the institution as the rest are self-committed and could voluntarily leave at any time. Whether their insane or not, the hospital is undeniably in control of the fates of its patients. When he takes the group of patients fishing, he symbolizes Christ leading his twelve disciples to the sea to "test their faith" as he brings these men out into the real world to experience what freedom feels like.
The movie peaks when McMurphy sneaks two women, Candy and Rose, into the ward bribing the night guard to throw a secret christmas party for the night because of Nurse Ratched's absence. After partying all night McMurphy and Chief prepare to escape the hospital once again they invite Billy but he refuses. Ratchet arrives in the morning to find the ward in complete disarray with most of the patients passed out drunk. Meanwhile moments later, McMurphy is once again trying to escape while Billy commits suicide he stops and flies into a rage and pins Ratched to the floor, choking her with both hands until one of the guards knock him out. As Ratched comes back to the ward with a neck brace and scratchy voice, rumors spread that McMurphy has escaped in order to avoid being taken "upstairs" but later in the night he is returned to his bed. Chief hovers over McMurphys bed as hes sleeping and notices he's completely limp and unresponsive. He then flips his head up and discovers the lobotomy scars on his forehead.
The movie comes to an end when the viewers see this emotional ending to the movie when Chief smothers McMurphy with a pillow in an act of mercy but resolves when he is finally able to lift the hydrotherapy foundation out of the floor and throws it through the window and escapes into the night, cheered on by all McMurphys fellow patients, ending the movie in a sad but resolved state. The film One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a one of a kind movie created over 30 years ago but still carries the message that masculinity can be degraded just as easily as anything else which clearly spoke to the audience that watched this film, giving it the awards that it achieved.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Awful if you read the book.
Review_body: This is one of my all time favorite BOOKS. After the first time I read this I rushed out to rent this movie to see how the transfer from book to film was.I was utterly disappointed. I did not like this movie one bit. So many important parts of this book were cut out or changed around that it totally destroyed the movie for me.I was with someone who never read the book and they seemed to enjoy it though.So, if you read the book. DON'T WATCH THIS. If you haven't, then watch this movie but someday read the book, it is great.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Milos Forman's 1975 film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" would receive a four out of five stars because of the cast, soundtrack, and quality of acting. Casting Jack Nicholson as McMurphy was a quality choice by the director. Jack Nicholson portrayed McMurphy's strong stature and nature in the book through his presence and behavior on the ward. However, I was expecting McMurphy to be a bit larger and broader as described in the book. Other actors in the movies such as, Louise Fletcher who played Nurse Ratched, was not what I was expecting. As a reader one imagines Nurse Ratched as an older, heavier-set, ornery woman, only to find her middle-aged and average sized in the movie. Another essential factor in the film was the soundtrack. A movie's soundtrack is crucial in order to provoke the emotions of a viewer. Music is a tool to set the mood of a scene or build towards the climax of the plot. Taking a look at this film's soundtrack, I find that the musical selections chosen were well-thought out choices. The edgy nature of the film extends into the score, giving it a profoundly disturbing feel at times. The music has a tendency to always be a little off-kilter, and from time to time it tilts completely over into a strange little world of its own. Jack Nitzsche, the composer of the soundtrack, did an outstanding job creating a soundtrack that assists in illustrating the life of patients in a mental institute. The quality of acting throughout the film is also exceptional. The acting among the characters is very believable and thought provoking. Sydney Lassick, who plays Mr. Cheswick, developed a character with whom the audience fell in love with his quirky, kind, and loyal demeanor. All actors and actresses produced a film that vividly showed life at a physiatric ward. The emotions fixed on the actors' faces made the audience feel those emotions too. In conclusion, the film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was an overall outstanding film earning a four out of five stars.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One flew over the cuckoos's nest
Review_body: Awesome movie! I like Danny Devito in this film. He's so funny! And Jack Nicholson does a great job as Randle Patrick McMurphy. One flew over the cuckoos's nest is probably one of the greatest American films of all time. And i'm agree with that. The film dares to be a tragedy on the human level. Life is often not pretty. Neither is this story. It is moving - deeply. But it never panders or moralizes, it just stands as a warning against the Nurse Ratcheds of the world and as an example of how wonderful good writing well-acted can be to behold.It is a Tragi-comedy/Psychological Drama. And Milos Foreman does a great job too. 10/10.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Honestly if you haven't seen this movie, you must. It's brilliant from top to bottom, from cast to story. There is never a dull moment, and the ending is just...magical.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This movie really did leave an impact on me, but the kind I did not expect.I was going into this movie not knowing much about it; all I knew is that this is a must-watch title, featuring amazing actors and a good production. But I have watched it now and I most certainly agree that it's very deserving of the praise that it gets.The movie surely made me think about the biggest ideal of mankind - freedom. How the movie portrays McMurphy's view of freedom, how he changes opinions of other patients, and leads them to freedom. It asks us the same question as the characters, like doctors and nurses, in the movie are asked - Is McMurphy really crazy?So...Is he crazy? All he wants is freedom: freedom to watch sports whenever he wants and to have relationships, to walk freely, maybe go fishing. Can we blame someone for wanting to live according to his own desires? We empathize with McMurphy, maybe because we can all understand that desire to live freely. And also we grow to hate the person who takes it away from him along with the character,and that is probably nurse Ratched. Yes, she isn't fully responsible for all the things that happened to McMurphy, but she is a visible obstacle for him, keeping him away from what he wants. She plays with McMurphy and drives him to insanity, all so he can't ever get what he wants.The true desire, him being so sure of himself and being confident, gave other patients hope, but it affected the Chief most. We can see that in the ending, which was absolutely beautiful. I can't lie, it teared me up.Also I want to mention that the music was AMAZING, Jack Nitzsche really portrayed the feel and the energy of the movie very well, with beautiful sounds of the cuckoo. I want to say this is a big contribution to film music, especially in the 20th century.Amazing movie, a must-see film, 9/10
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Jack is playing with his eyes!
Review_body: Great act in this movie.. one of the bests I have ever seen!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This has got to be one of my best films and i would recommend it to anybody.Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher play there characters extremely well and deserved all their Oscars that they received. This film contains both drama as well as comedy. It all starts when R.P Mcmurphy is sent from a work farm to a physciatric hospital as the people at the work farm think he is crazy but we all know that there is not anything wrong with his mind. We watch R.P Mcmurphy and his day to day routines at the physciatric hospital and his battle with the evil nurse ratchet and we continue the journey with mcmurphy through all his obstacles right to the dramatic end.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Awesome piece of art by alll the acters & acteresses
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This was one of the first movies I actually remember seeing. It truly opened up my eyes to cinema as a whole. When I started watching other movies, I kept trying to find ones that made me feel like this one did. 10/10
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: A masterpiece. The words can't describe this soulful story.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: this is a great movie that clearly illustrates the treatment of the "insane" in this time period.  it is by far jack nicholson's greatest feat as an actor and it also made other actors' names household words, such as danny devito and christopher lloyd.  it's a great movie classic that everyone should see.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
One of my favorite movies. Extraordinary performances and the story touched me deeply.
Very very emotional film.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
Really awesome movie based on true story
with shining of Jack Nicholson
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I really do not remember the last time a film affected me like this. Especially the first character of the story and the impact it had on the hospital patient community. In fact, those patients had succumbed to the rules and conditions imposed by the hospital authorities, and Jack Nicholson, by rejecting the rules and incompatibility, breathed new life into the patients and gave them confidence. We see the culmination of this change in the Indian character who eventually comes to his senses and escapes from the hospital.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I usually do not comment on movies. This excellent piece of work shows how insanity is actually a society and not a medical problem. Society decides who is insane and makes sure the individual feels insane and guilty! Especially the less "romantic" approach and character development give this movie a very real feel. It does not mask what putting away the "looneys" really is - a willful act of society to warrant conformity of the masses.Many philosphers deal with the role of insanity in society but this movie lets you grasp the problem with your senses not just with your intellect. It shows without veil what living in an asylum means even if the conditions of holding the "inmates" improved.This movie is a definitive MUST SEE!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The spirit of freedom vs. the spirit of legal
Review_body: Set in the early 60s, the story involves R.P. McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) and his arrival at a mental institution in Salem, Oregon (where the film was shot). He plays the "mental illness" card to get out of prison time, thinking it'll be a piece of cake, but he's wrong, very wrong. Everything appears well at the hospital and Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) seems to be a benevolent overseer of McMurphy's ward, but there are sinister things going on beneath the surface.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Billy <3 also DANNY DEVITO?!?!?!??! good movie love it!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
Very Good movie
I think so Redited movie in 2021 is good idea
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Our heart beat with Jack Nicholson and his nutties!
Review_body: The story of "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" is particular: at the beginning none believed in this film except Kirk Douglas and and Saul Zaentz (a producer,but a jazz producer!!), but finally the success was incredible.This film was the emblem and the swan song of a great and unrepeatable season.When America was crushed but still young and its cinema was dirty,utopian,visionary and rebel.In 1975 there was great film, like Altman's wildness of Nashville,like Kubrick's Barry Lindon, but won McMurphy, with his cap,with his basketball,with his girls,with his rage that push himself to jump on the neck of the nurse-jailor Flatcher and to pay,for the extreme rebellion,the highest price.And in the heart of many people won Great Head that finally destroyed all and conquest freedom.The hospital-prison is an evident metaphor of America, that stifles your brain and your desires with pills (or, if are very bad like Nicholson,with lobotomy). But McMurphy is always ready to remember to you that is very important to find a passage in the wall and to aim a kick to the indifference. And,above all to refuse the overwhelming.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Holy Hell I love this film.
Review_body: I could go into great detail about what every shot means; eg. The film opens on a wide shot of a beautiful landscape, a car in the distance, we watch as the car makes it's way towards us and it offers a moment to reflect on the freedom of what we are seeing, for we will soon be incarcerated with mental's all around...But I'll just stick to the main thing that moves me about this film. For me this film is all about a word, a word which I've never understood, I've asked many people throughout my life to explain themselves when using this word, that's a lot because people throw it around sometimes like it means something, but no one has ever been able to even try and explain what in the giant hole in the ground it means. The word is 'normal', we've all had our normality questioned at some point, whether it's talking, walking, eating, sleeping, jumping or uni-cycling across the Grand Canyon. This leads people, some more than others, to question if they are 'normal', some people don't realise straight away that 'normal' is a bullshit word made up by bullshitters to bullshit the bullshitable.The film covers Randell P. McMurphy (Mac) , a smart ars con who get's himself put in a mental asylum thinking it will be easier to serve time there than in prison. He meets a group of characters who are so different yet most of them are the same, they are all terrified of the world. Insert an extreme extrovert in with a bunch of extreme introverts and you know it's going to be fun. All the characters are brilliant and fascinating and I could right separate reviews for them all, but let's stick to the film. The film only leaves the confines of the asylum a few times but for the most part it is in one area, the ward, so it's dialogue that drives this film and each scene is a revelation into the mind of the other characters, right from the get go we have a firm idea of what Mac is all about, as he is uncuffed and transferred from police custody he jumps in the air whooping and plants a smacker on the unamused officers cheek. Right from this point I thought "Yep, I like this guy". We are introduced to our first crazy, Chief, Mac attempts conversation but is told by Billy, a young boy with a stutter he is a deaf and dumb Indian. The rest of the characters we get to know through 'therapy sessions' conducted by the films 'bad guy', Nurse Ratchet, if the name Ratchet doesn't give you a clue, she is the controlling and oppressive Head Nurse who seems to take quiet but extreme pleasure in driving this group of men under her heel, in this film both she and Mac meet their match in each other. The first act is Mac trying to annoy Nurse Ratchet, objecting to music and trying to change schedule in order to watch baseball, he meets resistance not only directly form Nurse Ratchet, but the men he finds himself trapped with, having been fed drugs and calmly beaten into submission they are unable (at first) to smell the freedom offered by Mac. The turning point in the film comes when one of the guards reveals when taunted by Mac, that unlike prison, he will not be released until the powers that be (whom include Ratchet) decide he is sane. This presents a problem considering the fact he has made people think he is insane in order to be committed. This leads us to the most powerful point of the film (for me). Mac confronts the other patients for not telling him this was the case. It is then reveled that most of the patients are in the hospital voluntarily and can leave whenever they want.This for me is the heart of the film, most of these characters have deemed themselves insane and are hiding themselves from the world. Now while crazy people do indeed exist, these guys merely think they are because of societies selfish and mean nature. Instead of embracing bad experiences in their lives, learning, dusting themselves off and moving on they took it as a sign they weren't fit to live as everyone else does. Billy is the prime example of this, a stutter will make anyone self conscious and he tells stories of a love life which stutters like his speech, he is not insane, unless you count wearing your heart on your sleeve a reason to break out the butterfly nets, but from my experience a great many people will tell you that is a wonderful characteristic. So he commits himself thinking it's for the best and Nurse Ratchet, instead of helping him, indulges this belief for her own bloated ego and allowing him to deny himself all life has to offer out of fear.We all know the end shot of this film, even if it's through the Simpsons references it's got over the years of Chief breaking through the window and running to freedom. Chief is the biggest introvert (literally and figuratively) that has ever been, choosing not to speak, cutting himself off from the world and just not taking part. (Aside from brushing the floor) But in meeting Mac, he sees the error of his ways and offers hope for us all by finding the strength to break free from societies conventions and labels and small mindedness. That's why I love this film, it remind me of the word 'normal' and the fact this an insane world, and I'm proud to be a part of it.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The best movie I've ever seen.
Review_body: The best movie I've ever seen.You can't die without seeing this movie.Because of the role he played in this movie, Jack Nicholson is my favorite actor and made me see other brilliant movies where he participates.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Not as good as the book
Review_body: I am an avid reader, and adhere to the belief that books paint a much more beautiful portrait than a movie ever can. And so when I finished reading One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest, I rented the movie, because I heard that it is one of the greatest films ever made. The characters are well cast and Nicholson's performance is haunting, but I was too distracted by all the deviations from Ken Kesey's novel to enjoy it fully. I recommend this film, but would strongly suggest that anyone touched by it should read the book afterward. In this way a deep meaning can be imbibed from the film, and by reading the book, the meaning will be reaffirmed and solidified on a more grandiose scale.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One of the greatest movies ever made
Review_body: Everything about this movie is amazing, breathtaking. Nurse Ratched is perhaps one of the greatest and yet most underrated movie villains in cinema history; power-hungry, controlling, and tyrannical, she stops at nothing to prevent McMurphy from bringing joy, or to a degree, the real world into the lives of these detained misfits. Nicholson is the perfect rebel, one has to wonder whether he is truly crazy, or so sane he can no longer take the insanity of the medical staff and establishment. This movie is as close to perfect as i've ever seen. One of only three movies to win the big five academy awards, this movie is most certainly my favorite. Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher deliver, the sound and cinematography are remarkable and the supporting cast is flawless.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Nice movie, not same as a book, but actors playing very great.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This Primo piece of cinematography is the hope I've been waiting for. Ken Kesey's amazing story could not have been adapted in a better way. This is one of the very few instances where the book is not as good as the movie, everything down to the ending to detail and characters. This movie is very well done in multiple departments and This might be my favorite movie of all time.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: You may not understand why the movie is named so even when you finish the movie. Reason being "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was poem chief remembers from his childhood. This part from the original book is removed in the movie, keeping the title.But Whats there in the name. This movie certainly has a lot to offer. These are the kinds of movies that inspire tomorrows film makers to grow themselves.Excellent Plot, superb performances by each and every actor. Hats off to the author, director and performers.I recommend you not read much about this movie, as it may bias your thoughts. Just go and watch this piece of art.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Has been voted as one of the best movies ever and is worth it
Review_body: My comments summarised in one word: Amazing. It is not only Jack Nicholson's acting, but it is also the storyline and its absolutely brilliant ending. How often have you watch a movie that made you look into wikipedia or search the internet to find more information about the facts/ practices depicted on the movie? Rarely. Be certain that this will be one of them!It is the acting of all of the cast, the screenplay and the very realistic representation of the life inside a mental asylum that gets you absorbed into the movie. You can see how some people hold a place of responsibility (nurse Mildred Ratched) while they clearly shouldn't be there. Does this happen in real life? Certainly it does. Does the picturing of the asylum represent real world situations? Yet it does. Does the acting of the mentally ill cast, although sometimes it might be seen as bold, add to its reality? Certainly. Do you get to share the leading actor's worries, dreams and hopes? Do you share his actions? It is one of the rare cases that you do.In conclusion "One flew over the cuckoo's nest", is a title that anyone who calls himself a cinephile should certainly watch. If I were to make a category of best movies of all times, I would rate it just above Alfred Hitchcok's "Psycho".
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The true meaning of the cuckoo' s nest!
Review_body: Excellent film in all aspects. as a viewer, i felt that i was a patient myself. it was interesting to see how the patients became all self conscious about who they were.jack being able to persuade them to change their routine schedule was proof that not all patients need the sort of therapy mental institutes provide.If not in some cases mental institutes help patients worsen their condition due to over medication and irrelevant conversations initiated by the nurses. it was interesting to see for every opportunity the patients had to escape, something always retained them to stay. for most of them, the institute was their home. they would not be able to function in society and may face rejection by others due to their stigmas. their fear of rejection is what kept them isolated in the hospital, not the barbed fence and secured windows. their only family was the ones inside the institute. Jack brought awareness to each individual in the hospital and made them realize they had a voice. when he died, a part of them died with him!the native Chief represents an important factor in this film. natives are the most discriminated people of our history.we see that he to is afraid to escape into the real world because of the racism. when he observes what is done to Jack in the end of the film, he knows he is better off out in the real world. He takes the risk so he can go to Canada where most of the reserves for natives are held. there he will be accepted. Billy killing himself expresses how the doctors and nurses had power to fear and control the patients using their weaknesses in character and personality. it is a sort of brainwash and manipulation tactic hospitals use to overpower their patients. taking away their freedom of speech, will to live is was really makes the patients ill. taking away their self- consciousness and alienating them of their existence. one normal man awakens the ones who are asleep and shows them they have freedom of speech and a chance for change. when his actions begin to work, the doctors fear him, so they shock him until he is a vegetable.this is a great metaphor on how the government has control over the citizens using tactics to manipulate us. making us believe everything we see even if it is not the truth. we as humans live in high secure society, but don't realize it.more and more are political systems are taking control of our freedom to live in order to have complete control our way of thinking and living. this resembles the metaphor behind this film. a good example is president Jfk who was assassinated because he wanted change and good for the society. Same with jack, he is assassinated from his essence as a great human being,to be left with no more identity and self awareness of himself.it easier for the government to stuff patients with pills so they don't interfere with the ideal society they are trying to construct with perfect flawless people.this film expresses how sometimes for some people, illness is socially constructed and not biological related. pressures from the ideal society is what makes them sick. two thumbs up for the written script and performances in this epic film!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Novels are always better than their movies except this
Review_body: I prefer reading books than watching their movies, because I can create everything as I wish while reading. But I do not believe that anyone can create this movie better than its director , players, and all its team.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
Review_body: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's NestIn the story One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest, the author writes about a man named Mc Murphy who tries to trick the system into believing is mentally ill. This man Mc Murphy believes he will be spending the rest of his sentence here, but little does he know that he is in for a rude awakening. At the beginning of the movie the author makes Mc Murphy's character seem somewhat mentally challenged. As soon as he arrives he starts yelling and screaming and his actions bring people to the conclusion that he is mentally sick. The author does a really good job of having the actors play the specific parts they are assigned to. They all play their parts with a lot of emotion bringing the audience to think that they really are sick. When Mc Murphy gets comfortable, he starts to observe and starts to chat with the other patients. The author makes it seem pretty easy to live in a mental hospital. All these patients look pretty normal, but in reality they each have their own individual sicknesses. In the movie the main conflict was with Mc Murphy and nurse Rached. In the movie the groups of patients always have to follow a daily schedule that is provided to them, but Mc Murphy does not agree with this so he decides to try to change their daily schedule. Mc Murphy tries to change the group meeting for another time so they can see the world series and the only way they can do a different activity is that the group has to vote, so Mc Murphy tries to convince them into watching the series, but all of them are scared to speak so he is the only one with his hand raised and of course majority rules. At this point the author makes Mc Murphy seem and act like a child, a child who is trying to convince the other children that it better to see a show than to be in a group talking about something boring. Well Mc Murphy tries it again the following night and this time he does convince others, but he needs one more vote so he can win and watch the World Series. It took him along time to find the final vote, but when he was about to tell nurse Ratched about the vote she said it was over and his time was up. Mc Murphy acts like a child by not giving up and throws a tantrum by acting like he is watching the World Series with his fellow patient friends. The author's purpose was to show a conflict between patient and nurse and that everything is not always okay. Once the doors close no one knows what goes on only the patients, but then again no one will believe them because they are mentally ill.In the story One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest, the author writes about a man named Mc Murphy who tries to trick the system into believing is mentally ill. Review title: If Looks Could Kill... Oh, I guess they can!
Review_body: One Flew Over The Cukoo's Nest is still a lesson in casting for any film maker. Jack Nicholson and Louis Fletcher? Ouch! I can feel the tension! Then look at the launching of some familiar names: Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd, Brad Dourif. Great novel, excellent movie!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: My first review. Stumbled across this today & makes me want to watch again. Actors fabulous, story interesting and fits right in with today's society of mental illness running rampant today. A remake could be redone I think, but hard to beat these actors.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One of the greatest movies and life lessons of all time
Review_body: Not many movies have won the "big five" in the academy awards. It's enough to win just best picture for a lot of movies. This movie portrays every film element to the highest degree, from the beautiful panoramic shots of the mountains outside of the mental institution to the story of ultimate redemption McMurphy and Chief find at the end.The movie is seen through the eyes of Randle McMurphy (Nicholson). He is sent to the mental institution because he would rather be considered "insane" and live in "luxury" other than being a jailbird in prison. Once he gets into the actual living area where the insane are, he looks up at this tall, native looking man they call "Chief". McMurphy's initial reaction to Chief was his little Indian dance he did to mock him, but once Chief didn't react McMurphy asked him if he played football and says to chief, "God damn, boy, you're as big as a mountain." Little by little, you could see their friendship start to unfold out throughout the movie.In One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, the title "villain" would definitely belong to Nurse Ratched. She gave threats to the patients, she was even friends with one of the patient's (Billy) mom. She also tries to toy with McMurphy's mind by trying to get him to conform with the customs of mental facility. It doesn't work out for her as planned. Including a classic scene where Nurse Ratched's threats cause little Billy to commit suicide. In rage, McMurphy has seen enough and actually chokes her out. This causes McMurphy to go through a lobotomy and become a vegetable at his stay at the clinic.I know many people probably disagree with this but, I think Chief killing McMurphy at the end was beautiful as much as it was heartbreaking. It symbolized that McMurphy, still had a chance to redeem himself and become a hero, even if it were death. It also gave Chief clearance to finally "escape" the premises and "fly from the cuckoo's nest", and how he did it at the end was classic. That's what makes this movie one of the greatest of all time, not only because of the sensational acting and the sociological significance, but because of the message and symbolism of the story.The directing by Milos Foreman was phenomenal, not only with the memorable acting by Jack Nicholson, but with the camera shots he used in certain scenes. For example, the scene before McMurphy was about to get electro-shock therapy they show a very close up angle of him to show the intensity and crowdedness he had to go through while getting the shock treatment. Nicholson also makes it pretty believable that he is actually getting shocked, by making "gurgling" noises and such.They actually go back to the "lying down" closed angle shot at the end of the movie when Nicholson passes away. I thought it was very brave of the director to keep that long shot of McMurphy's dead self, because by making it last as though it were a still shot, to me it seemed more and more believable that McMurphy was actually dead. I don't know how Nicholson just lied there stiff as a board. I know he may have won his Oscar because of his heroic and charismatic character, but how he dealt with himself in those two scenes is what tickles my fancy.The ideology of this film is, in my opinion, what makes it one of the greatest of all time. The story brings up the question of who's actually the insane; McMurphy and his patients, or Nurse Ratched and the staff? Clinically, McMurphy was not insane. Even the doctors and professors stated that, but since he didn't follow the norms and the dictatorship of Nurse Ratched, he had to stay at the sanitarium longer. I also loved the allusion of Chief, by acting deaf and dumb. He played the omniscient or "god-like" role of hearing and seeing everything, yet not saying anything himself. It almost seems as he was the narrating the story until he befriended McMurphy.I don't know if I could think of a more evil villain in a movie other than Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher). The evil looks she gave to her patients when they were doing something wrong was as cold-hearted as one could get. Also her audacity to tell Billy's mother about his sexual deviance is as sinister as you can get. She knew that it would hurt Billy deeply, which was a major reason he was "insane" is because of his relationship with his mother. He eventually killed himself, angering McMurphy.I never thought I would cheer out loud when a grown man was choking out a little woman, but I did here. This scene did a fantastic job of not making it taboo, but making you want her dead even more. This did change Nurse Ratched however, it made her a little nicer to the patients at the end and made her realize that if she abuses her power as a nurse, it can come back to haunt her.The meaning of this story is wonderful and helped Jack Nicholson set the bar for acting. The symbolism of Chief's and McMurphy's redemption serves as a corner stone for many many movies today. Whether it be the costumes of the patients, the crazy acting, or even the beautiful classic shot at the end of the movie where Chief runs out to freedom; This movie will never be forgotten. And it serves as a good lesson for everyone out there who feels left out can all come together and get freedom. I advise anybody who says they love movies to watch this film, because it will not only change your views, it will change your life and you can't say that about a lot of movies.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: After seeing the movie in IMDBs top 250 movies list. I watched the movie with more expectations..Its not up to expectations. Story theme is good, but not the way it presented.At the end of movie.. I didn't felt its a great movie.. Its normal regular movie.Actors performed well. Especially the way Nurse talks, expressions, they are the best. Characterization of each and every character makes real feeling.Jack performance is really good. Few Dialogues are simple and make sense.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This film was a total surprise for me as I became more reserved with much applauded older movies (like Citizen Kane and Zorba the Greek) which did not really live up to the expectation.The acting of Jack N. is absolutely superb; the story unfolds slowly and builds up the necessary tension until the last minute. The continuous blending of the crazy and normal worlds is so well done that in the end I was no longer sure which was which. This is a serious drama but every now and then there are genuine hilarious moments, of which a few are simply brilliant.It's a film worth re-watching periodically. For me it means an opportunity to reflect on our "normal" society/lives and fight prejudice of any kind.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Never get tired of watching this
Review_body: Never get tired of watching this movie.Every time I figured out how wonderful actor Jack is
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One of the best movies i've seen :)
Review_body: In One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Randall Patrick McMurphy, is sentenced to a short prison term for statutory rape. Believing he has found a way to cheat the system McMurphy feigns insanity in order to be transferred to a mental institution. Here, he expects to spend the rest of his sentence in relative comfort far away from the work farm he was sentenced to. Instead, McMurphy willingly signs his life away to what he has been fighting against his entire life, established authority. McMurphy's open defiance against authority, in this case head nurse Ratched, becomes a vicious self destructive cycle.McMurphy's condescending attitude towards the ward's policies attracts negative attention and only inspires nurse Ratched to "help him". This help would eventually lead to his lobotomy, thus killing his fighting spirit.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Should be in any film lovers top 5
Review_body: What can I say?  Its a true classic and with the Godfather, the best film of the 70's.  I can't believe it took me this long to finally see this film (just finished watching the film today)!The films true strengths lie in its exemplary cast, who are at turns, hilarious, tragic, and downright poignant in their actions.  This coupled with the film's powerful message makes it a film that easily surpasses something like the ovverated Shawshank Redemption (of course its different- but they share similar themes- freedom, institutionalisation, the corruptness of the seemingly unaccountable institutions).I really can't reccommend this film enough.  I'm just ashamed to say that it took me so long to see it...
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: over all critique of the movie!
Review_body: I have seen many movies in my life, and have many favorites while others are less enjoyable. Some movies are made purely for entertainment, and some actually send out messages. In the movie, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, the main character, Randal Patrick McMurphy, does enough in the movie that could be taken as a lesson.In the beginning of the movie, Randal starts out in jail for his assault-batter-rape sentence, where he is required to work in the prison farm. After spending a while on his term, he becomes tired of working there, and decides to make people believe he has a mental illness. He is sent to a psychiatric center where he thinks he will remain comfortable, and makes many friends, while serving his term. While no one's allowed to leave the center, he takes all of his newly acquired friends and decides to go out for an enjoyable day fishing. Due to his actions, he was judged by the head of the center and prison. The head nurse, Mildred Ratched, convinces others to let him stay and have McMurphy stay to get therapeutic aid, only because after a few weeks of being evaluated, he was caught as the center knew he was pretending to be ill. McMurphy changes the atmosphere of the center only to realize that he was better off at the prison farm. Every time McMurphy messes up, he goes through the pain of electro shock therapy. From all of his friends there was one, The Chief, who gained his trust and respect since he too was fooling the staff. Later on, when McMurphy decided to break out of the center, he threw a party, where all the patients were drinking and doing everything they were not suppose to. The next morning one of the patient was found in bed with a woman, and from the fear from his mother finding out, he committed suicide. when McMurphy learned about the incident, he attempted to kill nurse Ratched by choking her. He was taken to the shock therapy room, where he had gone through so much pain, he had turned into a human vegetable, and his body was dragged back to his room. Chief could not witness him in his current state, he believed McMurphy had no choice, and it was to reduce his suffering and was better this way so he covered his face with a pillow and killed him, because he believed McMurphy . Chief then used McMurphy's idea to escape the center, that both had decided to do together.McMurphy was better off at the prison, then at the center, where his lie had taken his life. McMurphy's plan was great, his down fall was, that he slacked off to much. He wanted to have fun, before getting out, which cost him his life.Chief played his cards right, and no one suspected a thing from him, and he got away with it. It is better to go through and serve the time for your guilt, then try to get out of it through a lie. McMurphy lost everything while trying to beat the system, but the system beat him. No matter what in the end, a person will still go through punishment one way or another.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a film directed by Milos forman. The film based on a novel by the same name written by Ken Kesey. This movie refers constantly to different authorities that control individuals through subtle and coercive methods. Randall Patrick McMurphy an imposing, red-headed Irishman, R.P. McMurphy enters the institution after he is convicted of statutory rape, yet immediately it is suspected that he is a sane man who chose the institution as preferable when compared to the work farm where he would have been sentenced. McMurphy is a boisterous man and a "gambling fool" who looks out primarily for his own self-interest. For Kesey, McMurphy represents ideas of sexuality, freedom and self-determination against Nurse Ratched's oppression. In that mental institution there was a nurse named nurse Ratched A middle-aged nurse who controls the institution where McMurphy is sentenced, Nurse Ratched (also known as Big Nurse) is a stern, controlling woman who behaves with a serene confidence. She is a mechanical woman who attempts to suppress all human, and in particular all feminine characteristics, but she cannot hide her large breasts, her one incongruous physical trait. She is manipulative and dictatorial, using any methods to assert her power over the patients. In comparison to McMurphy, Nurse Ratched represents ideas of sexual repression, authoritarianism and conservatism. "Ratched' who has a great influence on the patients. Mac Murphy didn't know that nurse Ratched has the power to keep him there forever. There was a challenge between MacMurphy and the nurse, which she wanted badly to win the contest. MacMurpy was having a good friendship with the other patients includes Billy Bibbit who committed suicide, a teenager whom Ratched has humiliated and dominated, and Chief Bromden a tall, half-Indian patient in the ward, he is the patient who has been in the institution the longest. Although others think that he is deaf and mute, Chief Bromden instead chooses not to speak, originally because others ignored him and then out of fear of Nurse Ratched. With the help of McMurphy, he begins to speak once more and reassert himself against Nurse Ratched and her workers. Chief was mostly ignored because of being mute, but also respected because of his size. MacMurpy saw in Billy a younger brother figure, and he wanted to teach him how to have fun. One night McMurphy sneaks into the nurse's station and calls his girlfriend, Candy, and tells her to bring booze. Another woman tags along and both enter the ward after McMurphy bribes the night watchman. The patients drink while Billy flirts with McMurphy's girlfriend. McMurphy sees that Billy likes Candy and tells her to sleep with Bibbit. While Billy and McMurphy's girlfriend are in a separate room, the rest of the patients, including McMurphy and the Chief who had been planning to escape, pass out from drinking. When Nurse Ratched arrives the next morning she commands the attendants to clean up the patients and conduct a head count. A confrontation with Billy leads directly to his suicide. McMurphy explodes into a violent rage, viciously throttling Ratched. McMurphy is subdued and taken away again for punishment; he's given an electric shock and eventually returned to the ward. Chief Bromden, unwilling to leave McMurphy behind, suffocates his neurologically disabled friend with a pillow. He follows Randle's plan and successfully escape.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest is a film based on a novel written by Ken Kesey. Directed by Czech Milos Forman the $4.4 million dollar film is known as one of the greatest American films of all time. Its symbolic theme takes place in a mental institute where various authoritative figures attempt a consistent routine in order to maintain control of their environment.Things seem to change in the institution once the very flamboyant and rebellious McMurphy (played by Jack Nicholson) is admitted to the establishment. McMurphy attempts on many occasions to convey his basic human rights and desires by in subordinating to the stern regulations set by the oppressive institution, which later causes him his own very undesirable state of vegetation and then death.The film portrays a simple, yet forgotten, messagecheaters never prosper. Unfortunately, this is a very true statement. And because of McMurphys'selfish acts of riotousness the ward has lost a patient who committed suicide. Sometimes we as human beings get too caught up in our own lives that we forget about those who surround us. We need to remember that everyone we encounter has a significant reason as to why they're in our lives, whether we realize sooner or later on down the road. We need to take into consideration that others have lives of their own and perhaps something we say or do may affect them in either a positive or negative way.The film definitely sets a tone of morality and reminds us that everyone has needs of their own. I enjoyed watching this film and would recommend it to any mature viewer.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over The Cuckoos nest
Review_body: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest was a product of Kesey's time, he used to work at a mental facility. Also, he used to take medicine and he experienced how to be in a mental facility. The story center of attention is on Randle McMurphy, where he transfered from a workfarm to a psychiatric hospital. The two main characters that stood out the most for me was Patrick McMurphy and chief Bromden. The psychiatric hospital is based in an all men asylum. A movie like this expresses how unsympathetic life can be in a mental hospital or other types o facilities.Randle Patrick McMurphy is brought from a work farm to a mental facility to be examine of a mental illness that he can have. McMurphy is an all loving type of guy, and very charismatic. He was charge of child rape but never been convicted of. He decided to change the routines of the patients by watching the World Series on television, running the card table, playing basketball, and by organizing a fishing trip. He wanted for everyone to be treated as normal such as pleasing their needs. A major point of the movie was when he says that, he just is going to be for one hundred and sixty five days. It was not true because the nurse had to tell him when it was okay for him to leave the facility. At that point, he noticed that he should have stay at the workfarm. Also, when at the end he end up being like one of the rest because he is a near negative vegetative state to its most elderly patients.Another character that impacted me was chief Bromden. In the beginning, he acts as a dumb deaf person but in the end he ends up being the most the most intelligent and loyal to a friend. The Chief Bromden is a Native American that has been there since World War II. He knows all the secrets of the mental institution since everyone thinks he cannot hear. He was a potent man of over six feet tall but he sees himself very small compared to McMurphy. McMurphy teaches him to believe in himself and to regain self respect. In the end, he helps McMurphy by killing so he wont have to suffer as being vegetative.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: A few thoughts on this magnificent film
Review_body: Well, my guess is that by the time i am finished writing this, there will be more than a couple spoilers, so those who havent seen it may wish to skip this review.That being said, i have watched this movie many times now. Strangely enough, i had not seen it until just a couple weeks ago, when i bought it on DVD without having ever learned about it. Somehow i knew i would enjoy it.  To understate my reaction, I was extremely impressed.What truly stood out for me was Nicholson's performance.  I have seen many of his movies, but i believe that this was the first film i have seen of his that took place in the earlier years (well, Easy Rider is another, but that isnt necessesarily a Nicholson movie). Very few actors that i have ever observed have the simple PRESENCE that this man does within this film.  Every glimpse, every facial expression, his body language, even his clothing add to his performance.One of my very favorite shots of the movie is during the first meeting that McMurphy is present.  When he notices Nurse Ratched pestering Billy, the simple, unspoken action of him playing with his card deck is enough to convey more than any piece of dialogue ever could.  The posture reeks of defiance, the eye contact and facial expression reveal his immediate understanding and suspicion of the dynamic beteween the nurse and the patients.  It is no more than, perhaps, 5 seconds, but it truly left a mark on me.Anyway, the real reason that i wrote this is because i had a thought regarding the interaction between McMurphy and the Chief.  It seems to me that the Chief is representitive of the spirit world, and McMurphy is representitive of the hedonistic, purely human world. As the movie progresses, and McMurphy slowly changes his behavior, Chief actually seems to mirror the progression, except, he does it in the opposite fashion.In a way, it seems as though the two characters are actually one soul.  As McMurphy comes into the hospital, he is self-centered, arrogant, and seeks attention.  However, as the movie progresses, his attitude changes, and he develops a legitimate concern and love for the 'patients' that inhabit the ward with him.**DEFINITE SPOILER***Just prior to the first electroconvulsive shock therapy, we are introduced to the fact that chief is neither deaf nor dumb, and is infact a passive observer within this hospital.  Ironically, this moment of growth within chief, where he learns to trust mcmurphy with his secret, is mirrored by mcmuphy's initial steps of psychological and spiritual progression.  After the ECT, he displays a greater interest in others, as well as a subtl appreciation of his position.  Concurrently, Chief, though expressing his feeling of powerlessness, is growing in strength, feeding off of McMurphy's raw energy and enthusiasm.As the next few scenes progress, with the climax of Chief taking McMurphy with him through one of the most compassionate death scenes i have ever witnessed, it felt as though we, as an audience, witnessed the assimilation of McMurphy's soul with that of Chief's.No doubt that this particular interpretation is influenced by the naturally spiritual/enlightened nature of native americans, but even if completely unintentional, the spiritual connection and transition seem to be there.Additionally, when it is revealed that most of the patients there are voluntary, a whole new dynamic is added, not only to the individual characters, but to the interactions between them.   The idea that they voluntarily put themselves in such a place infers that they simply can not deal with leading their own lives, and require the close supervision and regimine that the hospital provides to them.Because of this, it seems that all of the repressed personality traits within each character instead become the dominant traits due to the ability to act as 'strangely' as desired within such an environment.  Once this is revealed, so much of the interaction becomes a 'play' of sorts.**end of spoiler stuff***well, all in all, its phenominal.  i could keep going and going, but i wont at this time.  I simply dont know what more to say.  All of the performances are inspired and moving.  There was not one character who I did not get to 'know' in one way or another. thanks for reading.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: An anti-establishment film that springs from the disillusioned sentiments of writer Ken Kesey, this film is in my opinion the finest ever made. Though limited in scope, with almost all of the film taking place in the confined space of an insane asylum, like the main character McMurphy, it transcends its limitations and exudes a universal promotion of human freedom.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: You can read the plotline elsewhere - I just wanted to add that I saw this at the cinema when it was first released and I will never forget the stunned silence of the audience as it closed.  So many questions hung in the air, but, by the looks on their faces - everyone understood only too well what the message was.  Powerful, thought-provoking doesn't come near....a fine set of performances to relish.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Im ready to die for this film.it is my life.
Review_body: go watch this. i have seen it more than 40 times. it contains life. u will cry n at the same time u will be happy. its the special quality of this classic. do not waste time reading reviews just go and see it u wont regret. it is multi layered. each scene can be understood differently. its the best movie ever made. the ending will make you speechless.no one can say that this film is over rated.according to me it is under rated.i do not want to go in to the details of this movie because if i start it will contain so many words you will stop reading this comment.it won five academy awards.it is timeless.direction is flawless.i became a fan of jack after this movie.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: You have to watch this before you die.
Review_body: This is a slow movie. This is pure art. If you are going to watch this be prepared. No alcohol or weed. Snacks are allowed. No talking to each other. No sleeping.You will be rewarded.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I watched this film finally, after waiting for weeks for an opportunity to watch it to present itself. I got so very excited about this movie, reading all the quotes, people's comments, and the testaments to the brilliance of it. But was it really that brilliant? Yes, it was a good movie, a classic example of the 70s style; over bright lighting, too-realistic makeup and questioning of absolutely everything to do with the establishment. Don't get me wrong, I usually love these movies. But this one fell a bit flat.*SPOILERS*I think the main problem was that I couldn't really sympathise with Jack Nicholson's character (and yes, i know, I'll be in trouble for this). It was implied in the movie that the only reason he got himself into the mental home was because he didn't want to stay in jail (the comment about 68 days where he finds out they can keep him indefinitely). So I could see no reason to excuse him for some of the "insane" things he did. His only reason seemed to be selfishness. When he did find out that it wouldn't be the "68 days" he was hoping for, he immediately backed down, and stopped being the hero and saving the ward. He just escaped. You could say this is good, as it is a realistic portrayal of a person, but there simply wasn't a single reason I could identify to sympathise with him. In the end, when he had a lobotomy, I was not moved by it at all. Yes, I think I would have been moved by Billy's death, BUT I already knew he was going to die, which is unfortunate, because I think that took most of the tragedy out of the movie. Stupid 20 to 1. Anyway, as I said, this wasn't a BAD movie, it was quite good. I just don't think it deserves the recognition it gets.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Well this film certainly makes you wait for nothing
Review_body: After having seen this film because it was so high on the top-list I imagined it would be entertaining and smart.Could I be more wrong. There was no brilliant scheme in the mind of the main character. Just another retard in a mental institution. And then there is this "evil" nurse who "wins" the movie. Now why the hell did I just waste 2 hours watching some stupid bitch control weak men?more details: So basically some of the characters in this film were kinda cool. I especially liked the girls visiting the mental hospital, and the American-Indian patient. And the main character most of the time. The rest of the patients were basically lazy, unentertaining boring characters with confidence and/or social problems. Like you would expect to find in an institution of this sort.And the ending sucked balls
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The greatest Movie Metaphor of all time
Review_body: Who among us is not in their own "insane asylum"? What keeps us from achieving all that we wish? Why are we afraid to free our spirit? Why do we live vicariously or anethetize ourselves. In this stunning movie, JP McMurphy is committed to a mental ward. When he discovers that his fellow inmates are there voluntarily,he is dumbfounded. MacMurphy makes them laugh and he makes them begin to think, much to nurse ratchid's dismay. They hold him up as a god, and for the first time they begin to take small steps toward independence. They eventually drain MacMurphy of his spirit but not before one of his disciples decides to overcome his fear and take action in one of the most breathtaking endings in movie history.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: If I'd had to choose a favorite, I'd choose this one
Review_body: Nicolson really convinces me that even brave, unconventional minds can't stand up to a suppressing regime that legitimizes itself on the idea of intellectual and psychological superiority. That kinda makes me feel sad. But the way his actions motivate others to oppose authority figure nurse Ratched, washes that feeling away instantly and puts a smile on my face.This movie made me experience intense gloom as well as intense joy. That's why when people ask me for my favorite movie I just always name this one.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I saw this movie a couple years ago, i was probably about 13. I watched it because my brother was going to play the part of McMurphy in a school production. This is one of the greatest movies ever. Its better than any other movie made in the 70's (the Godfather, Apocalypse Now, A Clockwork Orange). Its just my opinion, even though all of those are awesome movies. Jack Nicholson is awesome, and I had to tell my brother he didnt even measure up, even though he had the whole audience in tears at the end. A good movie for anyone. 4 out of 4 stars
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: this movie is great! and jack nicholson too!
Review_body: i see this movie first time when i was about 7 years old and i like it but of course i wasnt understand it. but now 12 years later i bought dvd and now i think it maybe the best movie ever made. if i try to see my future i think when i am 40 years old i vote again and then i give 10/10 but now only 9 and half/10
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The movie did not do the book justice
Review_body: I finished the book a few days ago and immediately went get the DVD since the book was mind blowing. I was even more hyped when realized the movie has won five Academy Awards. As it turned out, however, I was greatly disappointed, as many fans of the books had echoed. I want to start by stating I have ever expected the movie to follow the book entirely, for it is understandably impossible to cram a 300+ pages story into a 2 hour movie. The main issue I have with the movie is that the director and actors had totally misinterpreted the characters and the core issues the writer of the book wanted to convey.Nurse Ratched was this machine-like ex-army nurse who represented the oppressive and dehumanized aspect of the modern society; she allowed no one to disrupt her absolute power in the ward and was depicted as a manipulative and tyrannous person in the book. Yet in the movie, she was cold-hearted and sort of oppressive alright, but one who essentially seemed to have the patient's best interest in mind. Who, as a matter of fact, was sort of the victim here, having this random guy messing around in the ward.And McMurphy. Oh boy, he was the ultimate hero in the book. Flawed and imperfect like the rest of us, he came to the realization that his initial rebellious acts against the Nurse out of selfishness became a ray of hope among the patients. He then came to challenge the Nurse on behalf of the patients, in hoped that by defeating the Nurse, the patients would heal from their sicknesses. In the movie, Jack Nicholson captured the free-spiritedness of the character but no further. His action seemed to be motivated by amusement rather than self sacrifice, which, imo, completely ruined the purpose of the book. Of course, the movie itself is not bad at all, there were some substantial acting, certain messages worth reflecting. However, if you want to capture the true beauty of the story, I strongly suggest you to read the book instead.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a movie about a mental patient named R.P McMurphy (Jack Nicholson), who fakes being crazy so that he can avoid doing manual labor in prison. Although this is the setting for the movie, the actual theme is that of a person, McMurphy (Mac), providing better therapy to the patients of a mental institute than the doctors or nurses can provide. The story focuses primarily on Mac as is tries to lure each of the patients out of their comfort zones and into life. As Mac does this he becomes a larger than life hero in the eyes of the mental patients, and a thorn in the side of Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher). Ratched has a harmful, narcissistic need for control. Overall, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest does an excellent job of setting the mood for a mental institute both in the sound and visual department. The institute itself is run down and feels as though money is tight for upgrades. This really brightens Mac's colorful personality, and sets a nice contrast. Often times the dialogue is just a bunch of chaos because the mental patients get into argument frenzies. These arguments help give the feel of a mental institute, while also allowing the camera to zoom in and capture Mac or Nurse Ratched's feelings about the given situations. All of the above, along with realistic lighting, great camera work, and terrific acting won the movie its Oscars. Irony plays a large role in why One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest was and still is successful. There are quite a few situations of irony, with the main two coming from Nurse Ratched's need to control, and the "surprise ending". As mentioned in the theme, this movie focuses on how well Mac helps the patients in the mental institute. As a sharp contrast though is how much Nurse Ratched, the helper, is harming her patients with manipulation and brow beating. As for the surprise ending, well, that will be left a surprise. This movie is not unlike others that have come along, in which the main character takes hold of a group supposedly doing the right thing, but were not. Most recently we saw a similar character in How to Train Your Dragon. In How to Train Your Dragon, Hiccup, a young Viking, teaches the other Vikings that the dragons are good when it was common belief they were bad. Hiccup is being manipulated and brow beaten by society and especially by his father to kill dragons. It's not hard to see the similarities between Hiccup and Mac, or Nurse Ratched and Hiccup's father. It's an entertaining theme, watching one sole character change an entire group for the better. It is a universal theme that movie goers will enjoy for years to come, no better example of this theme is found than in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. I would find it unfair to a reader not to mention this; although this movie is a good one it suffers from a pacing standpoint. This movie's middle section is not unlike an action movie. What I mean by this is that in action movies, sometimes there is so much action that the viewer gets bored. In One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest the middle portion of the movie is filled with crazy people acting crazy to the point of exhaustion. If you can get over this, or find amusement in it, then this movie will surely entertain.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: The theme of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, is in reality a sociology question in the form of a Motion Picture. That question can be summarized as "What is the proper Balance between Freedom and Order?" Randall P. McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) is the central protagonist of this film. At the beginning of the film, he is being transferred from the state prison where he is incarcerated for Statutory Rape, to a mental facility for evaluation, following complaints of belligerency and violence. From the time he arrives at the facility he seems to enjoy disturbing the status-quo, upsetting certain individuals (Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) in particular) and inciting rebellion amongst the other patients against the authority of the nursing staff. Though this rebellion is often times uplifting, and seemingly good for the other patients' well being, at other times it is destructive and harmful especially during the ending of the film.Nurse Ratched, while often portrayed as an unflinching power hungry authoritarian figure, does legitimately seem concerned for the well being of her patients. Like McMurphy, the outcome of her stance, seems to bring both good and ill for the patient's fragile mental states. She is the main antagonist to McMurphy, and the two often square off, almost using the other patients as pawns in a power struggle.The film ends, after several confrontations (each escalating in intensity) with the aftermath of a disruptive and forbidden party involving alcohol and sex held in the ward after hours. One of the more emotionally disturbed patients (and new friend of McMurphy) commits suicide after facing the social consequences of an illicit sexual encounter McMurphy pressured him into during the party. After this suicide, a visibly shaken Nurse Ratched, attempts to maintain order encouraging the group to return to the daily routine. McMurphy is upset by her insistence on maintaining routine after the death of his friend, and thus attempts to strangle her to death. After this confrontation, he is lobotomized as he has become dangerous to others as indicated by his violent outburst. Once Chief (a close friend of McMurphy portrayed by Will Sampson) notices his condition, he suffocates him (out of seeming compassion) and escapes in a dramatic manner, in homage to McMurphy's earlier attempt.Both sides of the quandary of freedom and order "win" and "lose" in the ending of the film. Nurse Ratched protects the group by putting down (via the lobotomy) the dangerous element of McMurphy, yet, McMurphy inspired the freedom of "Chief". It seems to me that the film wants us to ask how much individual freedom is necessary, and how much social control is necessary, yet answers neither for us. The film is different than say George Orwell's 1984 in that it raises the issue without preaching a message, letting us decide for ourselves. It also differs from 1984 by its modern day realistic setting, as opposed to the fantastic future of 1984, making the question more timely, as opposed to the more speculative and/ or allegorical nature of Orwell's work.The editing of the film was utilitarian, but that is not necessarily an insult. The film introduces us to the characters and situation at hand, without getting in our way with distracting "artistic" shots or melodramatic scenes (not that those are necessarily bad in the right context). There are a few places where the direction and editing do differ from the rest of the film, but these scenes are well done, and do not effect the feel of the film negatively.The first is the opening, where the daily routine as structured by Ratched is enacted as the nursing and security staff ready the ward for the day. The almost robotic readying of the pills, waking of the patients and starting of the records is almost entirely dialogue free, allowing us to see the precision of the status-quo before the arrival of McMurphy.The second is the climax of the film. The shots become longer, and the scenes slower paced, so that we can feel the weight of the various actions both past and present. As the consequences of both Ratched and McMurphy's actions come to light, the film forces us to focus on the human cost of the fight.One Motif Present throughout the film is the use of the Nudy Deck. Several times throughout the film, McMurphy pulls out a deck of pornographically themed playing cards, which he seems to play with during important scenes. To me the deck seems to reference his irreverence toward authority and the concerns of others. He also uses the deck to toy with the mind of one of the more simple minded patients. He seems to escape into them, when he does not want to bother with the world around him.Another Motif is the Mountain. In the opening shot, we see a mountain range in the distance. Later in the film Chief tells McMurphy he is strong as a mountain. Later when Chief escapes, the music that played during the mountain range shot returns, bringing us back to the image of the mountain. The mountain is strength of will.
