The theme of this film is classic. The question of how much power a person should have, as compared to that of authority figures, is one that has been debated for centuries. I like that this film points out the argument, without attempting to give us an answer. It expects us to bring our own assumptions, feelings and thoughts to the film, so that we may interpret it according to our values, and not those of anyone else.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: THE best film of all time.
Review_body: It has to mean something when a film ranks #8 in the IMDb Top 250, wins the five most prestigious Academy awards and is still considered underrated. Upon first watching the film, I was sceptical and half expectant of it being mildly overrated. The film is as close to flawless as any other film I have yet watched, and that includes some IMDb favourites, such as fellow masterclasses Shawshank Redemption and the first two Godfather movies. The screenplay and directing of the film is sensational. I have not yet read the book, or seen a play adaptation, but it is something I would very much want to do. The scripting is quickly-paced, but this never becomes it's downfall and simply adds to the sheer insanity of the film itself. Though, the velocity of the film itself does halt when need be - thus, making the more tragic, dramatic scenes even more touching and heartbreaking. The directing, from the excellent Milos Forman, is also something to shout about very much. An Oscar well deserved! Though, the film's stand-out of many strong points is the acting. Within a large and extensive cast, there is not a single bad actor and a handful of outstanding ones. Jack Nicholson, playing the hot-tempered convict Mc Murphy, and his usual psycho routine are as convincing as ever. As is, Louise Fletcher in her role of Nurse Ratched, without a doubt one of the greatest film villains of all time. She's callous, unpredictable and a role not many actresses would be able to succeed in doing so to any positive effect. Of course, the supporting cast, (and the "nuts" as Mc Murphy playfully dubs them) are outstanding. It's brilliant to see pre-stardom talents, such as Christopher Lloyd, Danny DeVito and the undermined Brad Dourif really go into there roles. Some lesser known actors, such as Sydney Lassick as the child-esque Cheswick, William Redfield as the opinionated Harding and the mesmerising performance of Will Sampson as the unforgettable Chief. All the latter three actors, sadly, passed away within years of the film's release.In short, an unbelievably great film - if you were to watch any, make it this one!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: R. P. McMurphy chooses to wait his time in a mental institution rather than have to do his time in jail, in the film One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. Jack Nicholson plays the character that would be more willingly live in the psychiatric ward than suffer his existence in the criminal justice system. Jack's superb acting capabilities shine in this film, creating a character personality that is realistic to the background of the psych ward. Over the course of the movie the audience has the opportunity to see the changes of these characters. It is these changes that help the audience determine if McMurphy's true ambition is to live out his criminal sentence in the psych ward or regain his freedom and independence. Nurse Ratched, played by Louise Fletcher, adds intensity to the film as the audience slowly learns of her domineering personality. This minor plot of the film increases the insanity and stupidity of the psychiatric ward environment. Nurse Ratched brings more conflict for Randle McMurphy and the other inhabitants of the building. Nurse Ratched attempts to suck the life out of McMurphy just as she has done to the other patients, it is obvious that she enjoys and needs to dominate the ward of patients The viewer must realize that there are just too many subplots to follow all with a detailed line of thought. Each ward patient brings their own story to the screen, it appears at times that these subplots overpower Randle's plight to regain his freedom from the criminal term and the psychological term. These subplots consistently appear to the viewer throughout the rhythm of the film. Intense lengthy close up angles allow the viewer to review every detail of each patients' facial movement, allowing the viewer to realize the true insane personality of each ward patient. Dramatic use of white on white colors throughout the film aid in creating the impression and feeling of a cold uncaring temperature that truly resembles the psych ward created by Nurse Ratched. These set colors keep the viewer involved within the insanity and stupidity of McMurphy's plight for freedom, keeping a monotone color portfolio supports the sterility of the mental hospital making the film realistic to the viewer. Like other films about mental illness, The Snake Pit or What about Bob?, the audience truly sees a change in the character personalities and their individual goals or ambitions over time in One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. It is the evolution of the character changes that continues to draw the viewer into the storyline. Are the patients ever going to get organized to break away from Nurse Ratched's authoritarianism, will McMurphy ever get to watch the World Series, and will Nurse Ratched ever realize that she is mentally ill, perhaps as much as some of the patients of the ward?
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: A Call to Defend Human Dignity
Review_body: The movie One Who Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) is a soulful allegory about the struggle for human dignity. It is set in Oregon State Hospital in Salem, Oregon. Randall Patrick Mc Murphy (Jack Nicholson) is the protagonist who plays a fast whit, foul-mouthed rebel who arrives at the institution for what he thinks is only 68 days, just enough time for him to receive a psychiatric evaluation and then be on his way. The doctors there and the legal authorities think he's been faking his angry tirades and rants just to get out of his work detail at a work farm where he had been serving time for statutory rape. As Randall settles into his life there and befriends the inmates, he immediately begins detest Nurse Mildred Ratcher (Louise Fletcher). Nurse Ratcher is the embodiment of everything Randall has been rebelling against his whole life. She likes routine, is predictable, projects fear and thus runs the ward that way. Describing his disdain for her he says to his psychiatrist Randall exclaims, "She likes a rigged game." She expects the inmates to tow the line and when Randall begins to contest he inspires the other inmates to do the same. Jack Nicholson does a super acting job of playing the rebellious yet heroic mental patient.When Randall finds out that most of his friends who are mentally ill are there voluntary and he is committed, he begins to further rebel and highlight the injustices that are perpetuated upon the inmates. He advocates loudly that the inmates be allowed to watch the 1963 World Series but is shot down by Nurse Ratcher. When a riot breaks out during group therapy where Mr. Cheswick (Sydney Lassick) demands his cigarettes and an explanation from Nurse Ratcher as to why she withheld them for him. He shouts to her, "I am no little kid!" After this occurrence the following scenes then show what happens when you stand up to authority. You receive shock therapy.As in the Shawshank Redemption, Randall is continually seeing to escape. He tries to get Chief Bromden, (Will Sampson) to accompany him. However, before he goes he invites his prostitute girlfriend, Candy, and her friend to the asylum for a night of partying. In the morning we see him slumped onto the floor too drunk to even go through the window he unlocked to escape. The sequences of events that follow bring the emotions to a height. Billy Bibbit (Brad Dourif) is found sleeping with Candy in a room and is ridiculed by Nurse Ratcher in front of everyone. He chooses to escape the pain of the moment by committing suicide in the psychiatrist office by slashing his neck. Upon seeing his dead friend, Radall turns on Nurse Ratcher and begins to choke her to death. The scene ends with Nurse Ratcher fitfully coughing after Randall is assaulted by the interns. The camera angle of looking straight down on Nurse Ratcher and her almost demise evokes a feeling of near jubilation.The movie concludes with, Chief, Randall's friend witnessing his return in the middle of the night from another ward where he had been isolated. He sneaks over to his bed and tells him he is ready to leave with him but is horrified when the lighting revels that the doctors have performed a lobotomy on him. The Chief does the honorable thing and to preserve Randall's human dignity, he mercifully smothers him to death. Afterwards, the Chief escapes almost as a way of freeing not just himself but Randall's spirit. One Who Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a well theme drama that entreats the audience to have more compassion for the oppressed and to also rise up and confront human tragedy no matter where you find it.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This movie sucked. The book was absolutely amazing, but the movie made absolutely no sense if you have not read the book. Reading the book prior to watching the movie, the movie felt like a butchery, all the thematic ideas were cut to make a pretty poorly constructed movie. Again, the plot of the movie made no sense without the prior knowledge of what was supposed to happen based on the book. Many characters were either cut or sidelined in an effort to make Taber relevant, even though it served absolutely no purpose to have him in the movie. Without giving any information, there seemed to be many important events and lines from the book that didn't make it into the movie, probably to make it a little more acceptable to viewers. This is disgraceful to the purpose of the book, which challenged the way society categorized and neutered the patients, so the director neutered the book.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I LOVED the book. The movie, not so much. Which is really disappointing since considering it's not that difficult of a story line to portray alongside the book. Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher did a great job in their roles but that is pretty much it.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I just watched the movie. It's a powerful show, but i won't be commenting about the powerful performance made by the cast.I think this show is a satire of the society outside. The nurses, the staffs the doctors, feel like a beaurecratic government to me. The patients of course, are the masses. The nurses don't repond well to any of he patients' problems, and give reasons and excuses for not helping them. Ther also seem to give an air of superiority and never treated the patients as who they are but treats them as what they are afflicted with.If you guys can remember , there's apart where the nurse Fletcher said that most of the patients are remanded in the loony bin voluntarily, just like voters they are.McMurphy is just like the anti-government that tries to change the little things that go on in the mental hospital, like trying to watch the ball game, or bringing the boys out fishing.A powerful show.... WATCH IT
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This movie is about a guy who is admitted to a mental institution on the basis to be confirmed that if he is indeed mentally ill. McMurphy upon entering the institution finds the people there are lifeless and to his shock most of them have personally volunteered to join the institute.It is later agreed upon that McMurphy is in need of therapy and thus must remain in the institution. The director makes the movie revolve around McMurphy trying to bring 'life' to the people of the institute. McMurphy quickly gains fame and thus the support of the retarded people. Together they repeatedly break the rules and regulations of the asylum and are punished. Believing he doesn't belong there McMurphy decides to run away until things take a very tragic turn.The idea of the director to break away from normal day routine and enjoying life is conveyed strongly by the ending which tells us that even though McMurphy himself is not there but his idea of 'life' is.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
My best Jack Nicholson's movie, a must see
Very tough situation and story, but Nicholson is at his best.
Amazingly genius
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Randle Patrick McMurphy (Nicholson) is put in a mental hospital with other people (some voluntarily in) who are not all there.
Review_body: Having worked in a mental institution for more years than I'd like to admit, I found this wonderfully entertaining yet tastefully done. To date, for me, this is still one of Nicholson's finest performances. There are so many great supporting rolls performed to perfection in this movie, it is unbelievable. Just watching Danny DeVito's first film performance gives an incite into the amazing actor he was to become. Louise Fletcher played her part so well, you actually did want to hate her. I can't begin to tell you how realistic some of those characters were (and I should know). If you haven't seen this movie you should stop what you're doing and do so immediately.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This is the best performance of Nicholson,and of DeVito too.It's hard to say that the people in the hospital are acting,they are so real looking. I think it's the ultimate presentation of mentally ill individuals that you can see on a movie. A REAL,unforgettable chef-d'oeuvre!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The acting is excellent, but the writing doesn't live up to the book.
Review_body: Well, as has probably been mentioned a thousand times, Jack Nicholson is brilliant in this film.  His character is so well built that you forget it's Jack and Randall P McMurphy become real to you.  The supporting cast is excellent as well.  Nurse Ratched is portrayed perfectly as a manipulative control freak.Of course, the acting is where the greatness ends.  The direction is decent, but nothing special, and the writing is just terrible.  After reading, and loving the book, I just couldn't like this movie.  Ken Kesey's novel is nothing short of superb, and the plot of the film adheres to the plot so poorly that it loses so many of the things that were great about the book.All in all, the movie falls far short of the book.Acting: 9.5/10 Overall: 5/10
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Good Film about a mental institute.
Review_body: I believe the film effectively used a few film techniques well. Those two techniques would be plot and acting. The plot of this film is used generally well. It follows the book for the most part and keeps my attention. The actors in this film are spot on. I could immediately tell who was who and they capture the character very well. The director chose very good actors for the characters in this film.I would recommend this book to anyone. If you have read the book, you definitely should see the film. There are some differences but it is pretty true the book. It's filmed pretty well and has some interesting humor in it. I thoroughly enjoyed reading the book and I also enjoyed viewing the film. They were both excellent pieces of work. I highly recommend this film.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Film Critique
Review_body: I feel that the film ineffectively uses the two techniques of characters and acting. When the movie first started the only three characters I could recognize right away were Patrick McMurphy, Chief Bromden, and Nurse Ratched. After viewing the film for two days it still took me awhile to figure out who was who in each character. Billy Bibbit was easy to identify by his stutter, but Harding was hard to distinguish. It took some time to see which character was who.The characters' acting was not that great in my opinion. McMurphy's actor was very thin and didn't look built enough to play that character. His temper towards Nurse Ratched was perfect though. Chief Bromden was the main character who's actor fit him perfectly. Aside from being an Indian man the actor was great at keeping quiet through the film and also his body structure fit the character. Nurse Ratched in my opinion was to calm and didn't react to some of the situations in the film like she did in the book. She was also described in the book differently than what her character looked like in the film. I would recommend both the book and the film for anyone. I really enjoyed the book. It starts off slow, but it is worth it when you get to the end of the novel. The film was also enjoyable. It contain a lot of humor and fit the book pretty well. There were minor differences in the movie that weren't in the book, but it makes the film more interesting. If you do decide to read the book, you should see the film as well.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over Cuckoo's Nest. Movie v Novel
Review_body: The book "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" by Ken Kesey and the film produced by Milos Forman did both an excellent job in performance but the film lacked very important detail that the book had. The film lacked character development and also the point of view of Chief Bromden was lost. I have decided to analyze both the film techniques. The film ineffectively captured the characters development in the play. For example, Chief is a mysterious character that all the patients have led up to believed was deaf and dumb. Although his placement in the film did not suit the placement he had in the book much of it was ineffective. Information such as his childhood past was vital piece of information for the concept of the story. It was never talked about or sparked at in the film. Chief's problems on why he is in the ward are forgotten in the film. Another example would be McMurphy; he was looked as a very rude and crazy man in the film. The book however did capture his craziness and wild side towards Nurse Ratched but that is not the all-around persona he had in the book. McMurphy character in the movie leads you to believe that he might be crazy because you don't see as much development he's still the same guy that stepped first foot in the ward. The film ineffectively captured the point of view. The point of view difference between the book and film is that the film has made it third person rather than the original first person. The book displays a first person point of view in the eyes of Chief Bromden. The film however grasps the book in a third person point of view. This is understandable because it would be rather hard to have a narrator who is supposedly deaf and dumb be our main focus point. It is a disappointment to know that Chief's story did not get touch upon in the film but the film did a good job in cooperating different perspectives in the movie. The movie and film are both excellent creation and both have their downsides but the reader should read the book because it provides very good detail and more descriptions in its final copy.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: i think that this movie is not as simple and easy to understand as it appears for the first time.and also it's not a comedy (or maybe black comedy).i think the director wanted to tell us lots of things and to send messages to us (not only a story about some mental patients in a hosp.and the brilliant thing (beside the genius Nicholson)is the director made his movie so that any level of audience can understand it easily.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: Great gem that never gets old
Review_body: This is one of the few movies that hasn't and will never age with time. An all time classic. Jack Nicholson is stellar as always but in this role in particular, he just knocks it out of the park.You can recognize some early faces of major celebrities such as Christopher Lloyd and Danny Devito. I've heard that the movie differs from the book but knowing the changes I think it still works. I don't really care about the Oscars but thank god this one got recognized back then, it would have been a crime to not prize this movie. Another thing I can say about this movie is it's subtlety. The main character isn't exactly an hero and the "antagonist" can't quite be categorized as a villain. It's up to your interpretation. I thought that was a nice to this masterpiece.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is the best movie of all time.  Jack Nicholson is amazing in this movie and the Godfather isnt even close to this movie.  Everyone that I have showed this movie to has loved it and said it was the best movie they ever saw.  Putting Lord of the Rings infront of it should be a sin.  This is the best movie I have ever seen.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew East, One Flew West, One Flew...
Review_body: The film begins with McMurphy entering the Oregon Mental Institution, and we learn straight from the beginning that our leading character is not settling for any of the rules. With controlling Nurse Ratched who is truly more scarier than any Freddie Kruger or Scream Mask and other patients from the wacky to the down right absurd. Yet however we can play fun at the strangeness of the characters, we can be reminded of how true to life this is, and the fact that it was actually set in a mental institution adds to the effect. Michael Douglas and Milos Forman have done an excellent job in making the novel by Ken Kesey come to life, and we must not underestimate the importance of Chief Bromden as a character as in the novel it is his perspective that guides us through the 'fog' Through out the film there is a daunting feeling the McMurphy's vibrant, laughing, card-playing and over zealous character is to be ill-fated. The end is well worth waiting for. I suggest that you should read the book first, and not after. Truly fantastic performances from all of the cast, and some notable characters such as Harding, Billy Bibbit and Marcini (I need to list them all really), this is definitely a classic and is very symbollic. As corny as it sounds, don't miss it!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Jack Nicholson performance is great. The supporting cast is also phenomenal!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
Critic: movieman1214 Movie: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) Rating: A+ Rank: #1
**SPOILERS AHEAD**`One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is the only movie that I can be spellbound and in awe after watching it for the tenth time. It is included on more than fifty Top 100 lists just on this site alone, and it graces my number one slot as well. Not to mention, it currently fills the number 8 spot on this site's top 200 best films, and the number 12 spot on IMDB.Originally written by the stereotypical hippy, Ken Kesey, `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' has been interpreted as a symbol for the way a sixties hippy would have seen America, as a giant metaphor for an American society that crushed and did not accept the highly liberal lifestyle of the times hippy. After this explanation, all of the characters seem to have a different meaning, Nurse Ratchet would symbolize a crushing American society, all the patients would be hippies who are now considered crazy and are put into their place by traditional society, and Randle would be the rebel that does not want to give in. `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' also has a literal interpretation that is, at times, more widely accepted: it could have been some sort of an autobiography of the when the author worked as an orderly in the psychiatric ward of a VA hospital. This interpretation seems to make more sense, but I would not doubt if the first is just as correct given the author's background.`One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' became an instant success among both critics and the public. Narrated by the Chief, the book proves to have noticeable differences from the movie; but this not a new thing for adaptations. The title proves to be misleading for the film. At first we naturally assume that the `One' from `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is meant to be the films protagonist, Randle. Although, after that final scene when the Chief dramatically pulled the bathroom water basin out of the ground and threw it through the window, achieving to do what Randle could not, we suddenly realize that the `One' from `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is not Randle but instead the Chief.The book's rights were eventually bought by one of the fans of the book, Michael Douglas. When he bought the rights to the book he had the play version in mind. Just about everyone knows that there was a play before there was the movie, but what some people don't know is that the first stage version featured the then nobody actor, Gene Wilder, as Billy Boy Bibbit. The play only ran for five to six months then shut down because of lack of interest from the actors.It is not hard to see that `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' the play, and `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' the movie hold some very close ties. After all almost the entire film takes place in or around the mental institution, with the exception of that one scene where Randle takes everyone fishing. Not to mention that another tie that the movie shares with the play is the same producer, Michael Douglas.One of my favorite aspects to this film is simply that is does not have a real antagonist. Some will put up the argument that Nurse Ratchet was the films antagonist but this is not entirely true. Nurse Ratchet is the opposing force, yes, but she does not mean to be. She is simply doing her job as she thinks best; she is not out to get Randle or any other patients on the ward, she is not purposely being the opposite force. Although she was technically the antagonist she was not meaning to be, I don't believe that it is right to give her the title of antagonist. Most people will come to the conclusion that she is the film's antagonist, given the scene where she refuses to talk about the cigarette ration with one of the patients until he sits down. She comes across as a menacing snob that could care less about the people on the ward; although Louise Fletcher plays the part of Nurse Ratchet in such a way that it comes off as if she was just doing what she thought was best for the patients.What makes this film great is the fact that every patient on the ward, although crazy, did not give in to stereotypical `crazy' roles. They were all playing a person with a different mental disorder. Most of the credit for this can be given to the director, Milos Forman, for making the actors pair up with someone with the same disorder the character was supposed to have. The characters were by far the strongest aspect of this film.The movie was filmed inside a real Mental Institution, the actors were forced to stay in character until they left the set to go home, and because so much of the film was shot inside this made a sort of ambience of isolation that put the film on a higher level. The casting of the various patients on the ward proved to be harder than it seemed. The director wanted to cast unknown people for the parts in order to get the feeling of newness when you watch the film. He went about his auditions by putting them all in the therapy format and he would play Nurse Ratchet. He would then expect the actors to improve the scenes based on the questions he was asking.Jack Nicholson won his first of three Academy Awards for his role of Randle McMurphy, but he was not the first person the director or the producers thought of when they were casting `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'. Amazingly, he was last on all of their lists. Before him were such people like Gene Hackman, Marlon Brando, and Burt Renolds. It was because of Jack's earlier films that they did not think the part was right for him, only when they saw him in `Five Easy Pieces' that they finally realized the man's acting ability. When they tried to cast him he was working on another film at the time, and it was either wait for him, or make it with out him. They chose to wait.When it was time to cast Nurse Ratchet, Louise Fletcher was, like Jack Nicholson, at the bottom of the list. The difference between her and Nicholson was that she was not playing the part like the producers and the director wanted it. It was not until Milos Forman realized that making Nurse Ratchet unknowingly evil would make the film more powerful, so he cast Louise Fletcher. As for casting the Chief this was the biggest of their problems. It had not occurred to them that there were very few large Indians. So they had a hard time finding someone, until a car salesman, and a friend of Michael Douglas', found this big Indian. He came into his carlot wanting to buy a car but instead was given a role in a movie.Milos Forman was the main reason why this film is such a classic. He was one of the few foreign directors that made it big in the United States. He directed two Academy Award winning films, the first being `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' and the second being `Amadeus'. Milos Forman originally got the job of director for being a director both Saul Zaenty and Michael Douglas respected, and for being cheap. The film was on such a low budget that they could not afford a big name director. His directing style was not a normal one. He made sure all of the actors stayed in character by filming without even saying action. He shot the entire film, with the exception of the fishing scene, in sequence. He paired the actors playing the patients on the ward up with real patients that had the same disorder their character had.`One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' won a total of five Academy Awards and became the second out of a total of three films in Oscar history to sweep the `Big Five': Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best (adapted) Screenplay. The only other two films that accomplished this were `It Happened One Night' and `Silence of the Lambs'. In addition to its five Oscars it also won five Golden Globes, various English Academy Awards, and Jack Nicholson personally won five different awards for his role as Randle McMurphy.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: About a year ago I finally decided to read the book. I was very excited. And for a reason - Ken Kessey is a great author and the book is simply brilliant! I was so in love with it, I decided to watch the movie, too, despite the fact that most of the movies made after books are... well, they're not that good. So, the moment came. I pressed "play" and... well, no. Jack Nicholson acted exactly like McMurphy would've but there were many scenes from the book which were missing in the movie. I have no idea why Milo Forman decided to cut them off but it was a kind of mistake. He could've replaced some of the other not-so-important scenes with the important ones. But besides all I said, it's a great movie which is a part of the cinema history. A pretty part of it.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This was the best movie that I have ever seen. And I've seen many movies.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: If there is any movie that can challenge the reign of "Shawshank Redemption" in IMDb then it must be "One flew over the Cuckoos's nest". It's a movie that will surely trigger some thoughts. Superb acting, super casting, and also sad but still super finishing. It shows us what happiness really means. Without any question, it's the best acting of Jack Nicholson. One will be surprised to find out that how a mental patient can change the life of his fellows. Though sometimes characters lose their exact path, still it's for the ultimate climax. This film also depicts that not only so called cheap commercial movies can attract the attention of mass people but sometimes movies like its can become a blockbuster! A must see movie. I would rate it 10 out of 10.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I had the chance to watch this when it first hit the big screens with my father who was a fan of jack Nicolson! true to the title this movie takes you to the depths and heights as it is a true master piece that you can watch over and over and still see something you had not seen or hear a line that you didn't hear the first time. An all time favorite of mine if you like a good deep movie watch this timeless Movie! In a word the Director did a fantastic job and Jack puts a most interesting and believable performance as the bad guy/just trying to stay out of the system as much as he figures a different way to get into more troubles then he bargained for. If ever there was a way to sum up the fact that you aren't going nowhere and getting there fast this is it.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: A comment on One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
Review_body: The wild violin music played during the opening credits of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest perfectly describes the movie. At times it is playful, yet there is a sadness that surrounds it. Our hero is McMurphy, played by Jack Nicholson. He is a convict looking for an easy way to escape the busy work that he is forced to do in prison. McMurphy claims to be mentally ill and is committed to a hospital, run by the dominating, cold Nurse Ratched. McMurphy makes friends with many of the patients, particularly the Chief, Billy, Harding, Cheswick, Bancini, and Taber. The main conflict is the power struggle between Nurse Ratched's absolute control and McMurphy's rebellious nature which inspires the other patients to become more independent.The most interesting aspect of the movie is how realistic it appears. The patients truly seem as if they were indeed patients and not hired actors. It can be seen in the background that the actors stay in character even when the camera is not focusing on them. It is also interesting to see that McMurphy does not fool anyone during his stay at the hospital. Although they believe that he is not insane, he continuously gets punished when trying to confront the nurse about her power games. To cure his "insanity" McMurphy loses his ability to think on his own. The movie ends with one flying over the cuckoo's nest.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: People who don't think Nurse Mildred Ratched's evil you have problems :P One thing at the meetings its the same thing day after day after day no progress made just the same conversation she likes to get the patients fighting one on one. When she was having that meeting with Dr. Spivey she wanted control, and even tho she new that McMurphy was faking the whole thing she wanted to keep him on the ward so she could break him in, not so she could help him! The thing is that she thinks shes helping the men. And the main thing why people thinks shes evil is that she drove Billy into suicide. She try's to tell the men "Lets try to get on with are day" I am not shocked at all that McMurphy tried to kill her. Even though I have seen this movie 20 times, I'm always clenching my fists hoping that he wins into killing her.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I usually hesitate to review any movie based on a Book,musical or any other medium before knowing the source material. However I can say that despite not reading the book, One Flew Over The Cuckoos nest is an excellent film that is sure to entertain any fan of movies. The plot follows Mick Murphy, a convict who on his last couple weeks of his sentence pretends to be insane so he's moved to a mental institution as he figures it'll be more comfortable. Well after several instances of disobeying the cold Nurse Ratchet,he learns he's committed to the institute and Nurse Ratchet isn't going to let him go. That's the main jest of it but a lot of time is spent getting to know the other mental patients and and their interactions with Mick Murphy, the most interesting one being Chief, at least for me. The cast what can I say? One of the best cast films ever in my opinion. You see many future stars in there early years including Danny Devito,Christopher Lloyd and more. Of course Jack Nicholson's here and delivers one of his best performances to date. I won't spoil the ending, but it's a nice, bittersweet ending to a film that's harsh but never ceases to entertain. Definitely in my top 20 favourite movies. Certainly one of the finest films I've ever watched.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: was the nurse evil did she keep him in the nut house to help him ?
Review_body: Hi I have seen this movie 3 times now and watched it again last night after not seeing it for a good year or so.it has to be 1 of the most powerful movies I have ever seen. I am a average 25 typical male but the ending does something to me which is hard to explain were I have to remind my self "this is just a movie" but really it is more than that ! to get to my ?. I cant make sense of the nurse in the movie. when Murphy is due for realise and the 3 doctors are in the room with the nurse and they all decide that he is sain and should be released.and she then she gives the story of that we shouldn't pass on are problems to other people etc.why is she doing this ?? is she doing it as she wants to help Murphy or in short words because she is pure evil and wants to undermine him ???
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: From the vague but beautiful opening shot with the eerie bowed-saw to the symbolic and tragic ending, it is difficult to not become fully immersed. Every role, even the non-speaking ones are played marvelously. Every actor, especially Nicholson and Fletcher, totally embody their characters. The fluctuation between high intensity to absolute hilarity to shocking twists and the breaking of the human spirit despite man's innate desire to revolt against such things, is captured here perfectly. It's the perfect borderline uncomfortable mix that sticks with you, one you won't find anywhere else because whether you like it or not, it's there and it's real. This is Jack Nicholson at his finest, possibly even at his peak. While it is quite different from the novel, the strength of the acting, directing and the desire for a grounded film shedding light on a subject that still has a stigma attached to it. Through the film, the funny scenes as well as the heart-wrenching ones, are all undercut with a realistic looming sense of dread. The acting, directing and quality of a screenplay adapted very differently from the novel were carried out and executed perfectly. This film is tragic, but enchanting. Hypnotizing.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One Flew Over The Cuckoos Nest is probably, along with Cool Hand Luke, one of the greatest films of all time. Jack was at his very best which, amazingly, is all the time. I think that Nurse Ratchett is the most hated character that I can recall. She was evil in a way that was familiar to many of us. I believe that, of movies that were made from books, Cuckoos Nest is the most faithfully reproduced. I've seen this movie many times and I always enjoy all the wonderful performances. Also notable are the careers that were launched with Cuckoos Nest. The almost unrecognizable Danny DeVito as Martini. The frenetic Chris Lloyd fitting so neatly into the band of lunatics. Will Sampson was inspiring as Chief Bromden. Cuckoos Nest, overall, coaxes such a wide range of emotions, from out and out hilarity to tear-jerking sadness, that it is nearly impossible to classify. Suffice it to say that One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest is one of the greats!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: If you like crazy things and bedlam,you have to watch this movie, it shows you the crazy men isn't as scary as you think. this movie is not just drama actually it's a kind of comedy movie too , and it has some oppressive parts too . but with all good and bad points it's a fabulous and unforgettable movie also jack Nicholson acts very well . mack(jackNicholson) made a heaven of a bedlam for patients altought for himself there was a hell but he accepted that he accepted all things in there but at the end he couldn't accept one thing and it was a reason for his die . If you like movies and you haven't watched this movie before, watch this movie as soon as you can ...
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I can only think of one movie adaptation of a great novel that was worse than this film, and that is "The Color Purple". They both suffer from similar problems. Both novels focus on the internal experiences and perceptions of the main characters, and rather than doing something creative, the film-makers simply tell the story and leave out the point of view. In the novel the entire story is told from the point of view of one of the patients. Sometimes he is drugged, sometimes he is in a fog and sometimes he's thinking clearly. To the reader it is as if you are experiencing being incarcerated in the asylum. All of this is lost in the movie. I really recommend reading the book and forgetting about the movie. Or at least read the book FIRST, you'll thank me later.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This movie is the ultimate legend of all movies, it's a true classic, this is the movie that changed everything. Made from the international bestseller by Ken Kesey this movie draws forward everything that is great in the book and gives it a little touch of more. Jack Nicholson appears here for the first time since he played in Roman Polanskis's "Chinatown", and he shows his finest performance yet, he is very convincing as the healthy/lunatic Randle Patrick McMurphy and his acting is close to perfection. Milos Forman's creation has to be praised as one of the best movies that has been made, his mixture of drama and comedy filled with very deep emotions make this movie a masterpiece of filmaking. This movie has a remarkable cast of actors like, Nicholson, Devito, Lloyd, Fletcher and Redfield and all these actors together are a winning formula. Many movies are made by a certain theme, some movies are drama and some movies are comedy. Somehow this movie has a touch of everything, the film is in all aspects funny, witty, heartfelt, disturbing, bizarre, dramatic and very realistic, the film drives on the mixed emotions of the characters and the audience. One of the greatest parts of this film is the music, the music, made by the genius Jack Nietzhe, just underlines the meaning of the film, it brings forth emotions that had otherwise been missed. It's a crucial part of the film and does the movie much good. This film shows us, like never before, the real lives of those who are locked inside a phychiatric institution, their lives are portrayed with utter realism. The way Milos Forman switches emotional gears is devastating, your laughing at some point in the movie and before you know you are suddenly crying. The characters of the book are great and they are very well portrayed by the actors in this film, Jack Nicholson's performance as McMurphy is simply one of the best that he - or any other actor- has ever delivered and other actors like Lloyd and Devito do a fantastic job. The greatness of the acting in this film lies in the very unlike acting of the actors, they each play a character that face different mental problems and these characters aren't the normal patients you see in other movies.When you watch this film you lose track of the time and your whereabouts, the only thing that matters is the film and the characters. Time flies and before you know it, the movie is over and you sit there totally paralyzed, a deep sadness over the dramatical ending is within you and at the same time a great joy over seeing the picture. You view the film and it has an extraordinary impact, you will be mesmerized, entertained and deeply affected. It's art of the highest order! Milos Forman, like Stanley Kubrick led us into a new era of filmaking, they made movies that had great impact on the lives of the people who saw them, I would definitely say that this movie is one of the greatest movie of all times and it has had a big impact on the viewers that have seen it and it has made a path that many modern films today follow. Forman, I salute you.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One of the greatest of all time
Review_body: One of the best movies of all time. I've never seen so many well played characters in just a one movie. Each actor did more than a great job. I did not doubt that any of these isn't a crazy person! not for a SINGLE moment! Jack Nicholson's performance was something else. Definitely deserved his Oscar achievement!Louise Fletcher's performance was as great and spectacular as Jack's! I'm absolutely going to watch more movies of her after seeing this performance from her!The worst thing of this great movie is the ending. I really hoped to have a more detailed ending than seeing Murphy die like that! I would have loved to see more scenes of him struggling with the Docs and trying to defend him self. Five of six minutes of that can never hurt nobody, i guess! but that ending isn't a bad one at all, actually, it was a very good one!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Everyone needs to watch this Classic! It brings out emotions ALL of them !
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: What can i say more about this masterpiece i think that all i can say it was already been said. The only thing i want to remember is that sometimes is better to watch again and again some old movies like this one to remember what cinema is. During these last years is becoming a fact that the budget is the main ingredient you need to make a great movie. I think that this movie is a clear example that it isn't the truth in fact Forman disposed a little budget making one of the greatest movie of all times.The only ingredient that is essential is the talent and the will to give great emotions with your movie.Too many people are forgetting these two things thinking too much at the money.This is why i think that "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" is a hope for everyone who wants to make movies.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: 'Twas Prime, 'twas sad. It was all the emotions and all of the feels. Plus Jack Nicholson. therefore Prime.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One flew over the cuckoo's nest shows a Jack Nicholson quite right for the character of Randle McMurphy, it is easy to fall in love with the characters of the psychiatric center, each of them has its very peculiar way of being, We see a Danny De Vito before being famous. This movie shows us that wanting too much control to keep right in a person can also be harmful, the ruthless nurse makes him an easy character to hate. We could summarize that "McMurphy" is represented as the freest man who acts against established authority, which constitutes the great act of freedom, or rather, the essential human act. Indeed, he is the only individual within the great mass, who thinks that the act of disobeying and being free is the act of reason. But in this world, freedom has a cost and above all in such an authoritarian system. In general a movie that ends up liking, a brilliant overall performance and a entertaining story.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One flew over the cuckoo's nest is a gripping drama about the psychiatrist world. Randall Mc Murphy, who wants to escape from his labour duties in prison, pleads mental illness, for being admitted in a mental institution. There, he will struggle with an oppressive nurse who enjoys persecuting the patients and who gains power everyday thanks to their fear. Mc Murphy and their inmates will finally their join force against the despotic nurse to work out a plan of escape.I absolutely adored this moving film, which shows us the rough life of inmates and how the nurses can bully their patients. Even if this film can disturb some sensitive watchers, I found very interesting the fact that
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: By far one of my favorite films ever produced. If you have yet to see this film I highly recommend watching it. It seems as if Nicholson was born to play his character in this film, McMurphy.I myself am only twenty years of age, but I'm able to differentiate a poorly made film from one made to last the ages. Big props to Milo Forman for his outstanding directing and it isn't a surprise that he won an Academy Award for Best Director of the year (1975. If you're to take a look at its box office success you're going to see that people at the time realized the issues portrayed in the film along with the ride One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest provided was well worth the cost of a ticket and popcorn. This film won several other awards as well including an Academy Award for Best Actor, Jack Nicholson, who in my opinion was at his prime during production of this film.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: reasons why I love One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
Review_body: why I love One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest ?1- Which one of you nuts has got any guts?2- The Chief, he's got his hand up! Look!3- The Cold Heartless Louise Fletcher 4- The Heroic Rebel McMurphy 5- first film to take all the major awards (Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor, and Best Actress) since It Happened One Night6- McMurphy commenting a match on TV Closed7- the voting 8- Nicholson convincing the boats guy that they are doctors 9- "Well I tried, didn't I? At least I did that," 10- great supporting cast. This is movie I wish kubrick has made this is his area : standing against Fascism
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Absolutely Amazing. My favourite film ever. For one film to have so any career best performances by everyone who is in it, it shows the greatness of the picture. Jack puts his spin on the James Dean type character, and does it better than Jimmy. The film puts you through every emotion. From an amazing novel develops an even better movie. The film accepts the viewer into its wacky bunch of comic-book characters and you become friends with them instantly. Amazing Direction and Photography. Many laugh out loud moments as well as emotional ones, this resulting in a personally epic emotional roller-coaster movie. Must see for anyone.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One of the best drama movies ever made
Review_body: What's to say about this movie? Great direction, great actors , great script.It rightfully won the top 5 Oscars and it is definitely worth seeing.The film depicts the story of a man who got closed in an asylum because he was considered crazy.Although he was just a danger to the system by his ideals and beliefs.During the film though we understand that he is mentally stabled (NICHOLSON'S CHARACTER). Even though his extremely egoistic character Nicholson , finds a way to get in the psychology of every person in the asylum and make them happy in some way.The ending may seem upsetting at first but the director will not let you down as always
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: This movie gets a 9 for me because at the time of the movie, it is so cleverly written and directed so beautifully that its simply a joy to watch. It captures the magic of a movie fantastically. By that i mean there are moments that make you smile and their are many moments that make you laugh! absolutely worth a watch! The relationship between certain characters really warms your heart. Jack Nicolson takes us on a journey that allows us to develop empathy towards the other characters but his love for life and quirky sense of humour makes us learn to listen to him and also makes us question his emotional state. This film holds emotional value for me because it was introduced to me from my father who loved it! The movie isn't too long, it leaves you feeling a restored faith in humanity.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The right film if you wanna watch THE FILM
Review_body: I love "One flew over the cuckoo's nest". I thing this is one of the best films in the cinema's history. This is a 10 movie. One of the greats hits. This is the perfect movie, except if you are looking for a cheap comedy. This film is an A because of its cast and performance (Jack Nicholson), its direction (Milos Forman), its script and stage design. Congratulations if you have seen this movie. You can say you know History of Film. ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST is THE MOVIE. I can't stop saying and writing it. Why? Because I love this movie and I thing is a great movie in an impartial way. One of the bests. You will like it, sure! You will love it! Enjoy the film today. You will not regret to listen to me. COME ON!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: The One film I knew the end, but almost cried
Review_body: When I was recommended this movie, I only knew Jack Nicholson was involved, nothing more, then I read some reviews, and, unfortunately, realized how the ending would be (No Spoilers).This did't mean I would't watch the movie. I was talked awesomely about this film, and I wanted to see how good it really was.When I started, I could't move away from my TV's screen, 'cause what I was watching, was a real "Good Film". Jack Nicholson's portrayal of Randy McMurphy was fantastical, also Louis Fletcher and Brad Dourif, who surprised me very much.Until the end, I was enjoying this "must-see masterpiece" without caring about the fact I knew how it would conclude, so, when the time came, I started to feel like talking to McMurphy, literally, to make him aware of what would happen to him. I was caring about Jack Nicholson's character, something Milos Forman nailed.I won't say what happens, because that's something you need to find out, but what I can say, is that I almost cried. The soundtrack, the acting, the cinematography, everything just before the credits is perfect.I really recommend this film, if you haven't watched it yet.Thank you Milos Forman, for one of the best films I've seen.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Cannot watch this film enough times. It runs the gamut of emotions. Makes you laugh, makes you cry, makes you mad, gives you faith. Truly great acting by all cast members. Nicholson is at his very best. The ending was perfect. Not sure that if they were to make the film now it would end but I think that makes the film more real. Danny De Vito is great. Josep Elic is memorable. the card game is absolute class. Sydney Lassick is masterful. Christopher Lloyd albeir ina slightly cameo role is at his very best (perhaps matched by his role in taxi). William duell is excellent as Sefelt and is reminiscent of Stan Laurel. However, other than Jack Nicholson, it really is Brad Dourif as Billy Bibbit who steals the show. I would class his as one one of the most memorable characters from any film I have watched over the past forty years. Cannot praise it enough
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: First time seeing this movie. I can completely see how it swept all of the awards. From start to finish, everything was perfect. No doubt one of the best movies I've ever seen!
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: In first place, I was asking to myself WTF is this movie about. But then I discovered and it blew my mind. I recommend this film,especially for Jack Nicholson's work, it was terrific. What a great movie.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: Even as I'm making these observations, though, I can't get out of my mind the tumultuous response that "Cuckoo's Nest" received from its original audiences. Even the most obvious, necessary, and sobering scenes -- as when McMurphy tries to strangle Nurse Ratched to death -- were received, not seriously, but with sophomoric cheers and applause. Maybe that's the way to get the most out of the movie -- see it as a simple-minded anti establishment parable -- but I hope not. I think there are long stretches of a very good film to be found in the midst of Forman's ultimate failure, and I hope they don't get drowned in the applause for the bad stuff that plays to the galleries.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: The film is very violent. Effect on the psyche and Jack Nicholson simply delicious!!!!!!!!!!!10/10 Picture - primarily benefit the actors and their game - deservedly received the highest critical acclaim. The Acting and Directing are I'd say an 8.The music is quite suiting and light in this movie.For anyone who's looking for an interesting drama film and has the time, this movie is worth your time.One problem with the film is that it's quite long and at times, draggy. Make-up wise this movie doesn't stand out. However the characters are very difficult and amazingly performed by all of the actors and actresses in this film.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: I've watched this masterpiece more than 3 times (for sure) and I think it is time give its proper review. Just to start, I'd say this is one of those films that you recommend to every person you know; it's a "must watch" without any doubt. In my opinion, what makes this movie such a well-crafted masterpiece is the essence behind the plot. Milos Forman, the director, showed that he could handle a complex movie without trouble. Additionally, he managed to perform a great job catching the spectator's attention. In my opinion, what we see here is one of Jack Nicholson's best performance EVER. You can barely differentiate between the thin line that he's crossing; you can't tell if he's acting or that's just himself displaying his inner craziness. And that's beautiful. The composer Jack Nitzche achieved perfection with the main theme and the movie's soundtrack. You can feel a mixed emotion between what is sadness, happiness, madness and gloom... All at once. That's what just makes this movie even better. Music fills your soul. To summarize, this is a great and beautiful movie with the perfect components to make you feel that you won't forget it. If you haven't watched it yet, please, do. You won't regret, I promise.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a 1975 American drama film directed by Milo Forman, based on the 1962 novel One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest by Ken Kesey
Review_body: In 1963 Oregon, Randle Patrick "Mac" McMurphy (Jack Nicholson), a recidivist anti-authoritarian criminal serving a short sentence on a prison farm for the statutory rape of a 15-year-old girl, is transferred to a mental institution for evaluation. Although he does not show any overt signs of mental illness, he hopes to avoid hard labor and serve the rest of his sentence in a more relaxed hospital environment.McMurphy's ward is run by steely, unyielding Nurse Mildred Ratched (Louise Fletcher), who employs subtle humiliation, unpleasant medical treatments and a mind-numbing daily routine to suppress the patients. McMurphy finds that they are more fearful of Ratched than they are focused on becoming functional in the outside world. McMurphy establishes himself immediately as the leader; his fellow patients include Billy Bibbit (Brad Dourif), a nervous, stuttering young man; Charlie Cheswick (Sydney Lassick), a man disposed to childish fits of temper; Martini (Danny DeVito), who is delusional; Dale Harding (William Redfield), a high-strung, well-educated paranoid; Max Taber (Christopher Lloyd), who is belligerent and profane; Jim Sefelt (William Duell), who is epileptic; and "Chief" Bromden (Will Sampson), a silent Native American of imposing stature who is believed to be deaf and mute.McMurphy's and Ratched's battle of wills escalates rapidly. When McMurphy's card games win away everyone's cigarettes, Ratched confiscates the cigarettes and rations them out. McMurphy calls for votes on ward policy changes, to watch the World Series, to challenge her. He makes a show of betting the other patients he can escape by lifting an old hydrotherapy console, a massive marble plumbing fixture, off the floor and sending it through the window; but fails to do so.McMurphy steals a hospital bus, herds his colleagues aboard, stops to pick up Candy (Marya Small), a party girl, and takes the group deep sea fishing on a commandeered boat. He tells them: "You're not nuts; you're fishermen!" and they begin to feel faint stirrings of self-determination.Soon after, however, McMurphy learns that Ratched and the doctors have the power to keep him committed indefinitely. Sensing a rising tide of insurrection among the group, Ratched tightens her grip on everyone. During one of her group therapy sessions, Cheswick's agitation boils over and he, McMurphy and the Chief wind up brawling with the orderlies.While McMurphy and the Chief wait their turn, McMurphy offers Chief a piece of gum, and Chief murmurs "Thank you...Ah, Juicy Fruit." McMurphy is delighted to find that Bromden is neither deaf nor mute, and that he stays silent to deflect attention. After the electroshock therapy, McMurphy shuffles back onto the ward feigning brain damage, before humorously animating his face and loudly greeting his fellow patients, assuring everyone that the Etc only charged him up all the more.As the struggle with Ratched takes its toll, and with his release date no longer a certainty, McMurphy plans an escape. He phones Candy to bring her friend Rose (Louisa Moritz) and some booze to the hospital late one night. They enter through a window after McMurphy bribes the night orderly, Mr. Turkle (Scatman Crothers). McMurphy and Candy invite the patients into the day room for a Christmas party; the group breaks into the drug locker, puts on music, and celebrates. At the end of the night, McMurphy and Bromden prepare to climb out the window with the girls. McMurphy says goodbye to everyone, and invites an emotional Billy to escape with them; he declines, saying he is not yet ready to leave the hospital—though he would like to date Candy in the future. McMurphy insists Billy have sex with Candy right then and there. Billy and Candy agree and they retire to a private room. The effects of the alcohol and pilfered medication take their toll on everyone, including McMurphy and the Chief, whose eyes slowly close in fatigue.Ratched arrives the following morning and discovers the scene: the ward completely upended and patients passed out all over the floor. She orders the attendants to lock the window, clean up, and conduct a head count. When they find Billy and Candy, the other patients applaud and, buoyed, Billy speaks for the first time without a stutter. Ratched then announces that she will tell Billy's mother what he has done. Billy panics, his stutter returns, he starts punching himself and then locks himself in the doctor's office. Locked inside, Billy kills himself. McMurphy, enraged at Ratched, chokes her nearly to death until orderly Washington knocks him out.Some time later, the patients in the ward play cards and gamble for cigarettes as before, only now with Harding dealing and delivering a pale imitation of McMurphy's patter. Ratched, still recovering from the neck injury sustained during McMurphy's attack, wears a neck brace and speaks in a thin, reedy voice. The patients pass a whispered rumor that McMurphy dramatically escaped the hospital rather than being taken "upstairs".Late that night, Bromden sees McMurphy being escorted back to his bed, and initially believes that he has returned so they can escape together, which he is now ready to do since McMurphy has made him feel "as big as a mountain". However, when he looks closely at McMurphy's unresponsive face, he is horrified to see lobotomy scars on his forehead. Unwilling to allow McMurphy to live in such a state, the Chief smothers McMurphy to death with his pillow. He then carries out McMurphy's escape plan by lifting the hydrotherapy console off the floor and hurling the massive fixture through a grated window. Chief climbs through the window and runs off into the distance, with Taber waking up just in time to see him escape and cheering as the others awake.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: One of my all time favorite movies. Jack Nicholson has the part down perfect and the supporting cast of "nuts" seem to make it all come together perfectly. A low budget film that made millions. The film was set in the 60;s and filmed at the Montana State Hospital in Galen, Montana. The "Chief" in the movie is a good side kick of reality for Jacks character. The reality is also that of what happens to people once put into a insane asylum. Crazy or not. Many times the movie brings you to think, "what if it was me"? I watch very few movies twice. This is a picture that you can do that ! The "Ringleader" Mr. McMurphy takes charge of movie from the beginning.
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body:
Amazing movie.
I watch this movie every time I get bad, and everything gets better.
Awesome atmosphere and play of actors at a very high level.
Jack Nicholson, Louise Fletcher, Daniel DeVito - a great cast.

Review_body: There is an on-going argument in my household pertaining to this movie. Most of you will think this is a ridiculous question, but it might finally get my dad to cease his attempts to waver my opinion. My father seems to believe that when Nicholson is lifting the large fountain, to try to escape he releases some gas. I completely disagree and believe he is just straining. If you don't know what I'm talking about, watch that scene again and give me your take. I don't think that this will change my dad's mind since that everyone has their own opinion, but I was just curious to see what everyone else thinks.Thanks
Movie_name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

Review_body: That was a great movie of all the time. Their story was perfect and nicely performed. All played an excellent role.I start crying at the scene that a healthy man converted into insane one. I liked the very last scene when Indian follows the same scene that his friend imagined. It takes me to land on their own. Thanks to IMDb and their users. Thanks a lot!
